There is a well stocked convience store on the property as well as other shops. We bought cereal and pop tarts here for breakfast most days. Beach towels are free to check out. Staff was friendly throughout the hotel. Rooms very clean with great air conditioning. Room had a nice sized safe that will fit a laptop and various valuables.Negatives...Room was pretty small. We found our selves very crowded with all our luggage out. They have a dresser and closet space to hang clothes. But only staying four days, we did not utilize much of it. They have an activities desk where you can book tours and rent beach equipment and lessons. However the attendent was never around when we wanted to find info. Not sure if she is directly related to the hotel or not. It is about a 10-15min walk to waikiki, 2 paths street or a nice beach walk. At night this walk can be bit daunting do to the homeless folks who set up camp in the park or live out of their cars along the street. We did not have any problems but you were definetly on alert. Conclusion....This is a very japanese hotel. Reflective of room size and various policies and of course clientel. Great hotel for middle age and older couples. Away from the hustle of waikik but with in walking distance to all the action. Overall we enjoyed our stay, as we are in our thirties and like to be active but have a nice retreat at the end of the day. A note about oahu. Most activities close around 5pm. If you are a late riser. You wont get half the stuff on you list done.
user_name:
Justin O
Indianapolis, Indiana, United States

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: After staying at the Royal Hawaiian and a fantastic place in Maui, New Otani kind of felt like the holiday inn of hotel. I probably shouldn't compare, it served its purpose, clean, affordable and quiet. It is quite small, and I'm a small person. no problem for business travellers or people who don't plan to spend any time in the room. The restaurant at the hotel wasn't that great but the service was polite, they even held our luggage for a few days while we went to Maui (you have to pay for carry-on on that flight). It was about a 15 minute walk to the 'core' of waikiki'. My advice: avoid Waikiki altogether - hawaii has way more to offer outside it.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed at the New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel for 2 nights recently and we had a great time from the moment we walked in the doors. We received an upgrade to a full ocean view room on the corner and my goodness what a cracker of a view we got. It was everything we could have hoped for. It is an older Hotel but I would regard it as boutique. I will be staying there every time I go back to Honolulu. We spent a night at the Hilton Hawaiian Village and it wasn't scratch on the New Otani. It is a walk but only a short one from the main part of Waikiki but believe me this is one of the jewels of this Hotel. Only $5.00 in a cab or take the Bus. The beach at the New Otani is the best beach in Waikiki. Give it go I will be surprised if it disappoints.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I am giving this hotel a "poor" rating because of what you get for the price. Generally, in the universe of hotels, the New Otani is probably "average" or just below average. But when the price hovers around $400 per night (then add valet parking, the "resort fee" for which you get the use of beach towels and spotty internet and not much else that I could see, and the cost of having to eat out for most meals for the term of the stay to that per-night cost), the experience should be, at the very least, very good. This was not. We've stayed at the Grand Hyatt and at Kuhio Shores condos on Kauai, the Ritz on Maui, and Horizon House on the Big Island, and by comparison the New Otani has the terrible honor of having been the most expensive and the worst - by far - of the bunch.The view from the Queen suite was a show-stopper, that's true. But after staying there 9 (yes, that's nine) days, my perspective is that we were pretty much paying only for that view.The staff was - with a couple of exceptions - not very friendly, or very helpful. There was one valet (mentioned in other reviews on Yelp, I noticed today) who was very nice, helpful by offering tips for snorkel sites and directions, and who was also very interesting and talked with us about the hotel's (in my opinion short-sighted and antiquated) policy of not permitting staff to have tattoos showing even when the tattoos are expressions of native culture being worn by Hawaiian people. He was kind and welcoming to us, and actually remembered that we were guests there when we saw him day after day, unlike his co-workers.The other valets seemed annoyed by us. At other hotels we've stayed at, valets would help (or at least offer to help) with our snorkeling equipment and bags from our day trips; here, they uniformly did not ask whether we needed help, and would stand there as we struggled to get everything out of the car quickly so as not to hold up the valet line. A couple of the valets either couldn't remember or pretended that they didn't remember that we were actually guests (asking us if we were checking in when we'd been staying there almost a week and had encountered this particular person multiple times), and that we were together (asking my partner for her valet ticket number, and then asking me for mine, even though we were standing inches apart, had come down the stairs together, were engaged in conversation with each other, and were pretty obviously "together" - traveling together at least, even if these individuals didn't recognize us as a couple).Other staff members questioned my request for four beach towels for two of us ("Four of you in your room?!" "Um, no, but as you can see I'm a larger person, so it's helpful for me to have two towels..." and do I really need to explain this to you when I'm standing right in front of you, there is a closet full of towels right there next to us, and I've only asked for 4 of them for 2 people for a day of swimming, which doesn't seem excessive?). Another gave us partial and incorrect information about the hotel restaurants. The beachfront restaurant, while always crowded for dinner, had limited hours and likewise limited and also somewhat strange food options (very little for the vegetarian; didn't even have any bread that they could serve with her paltry iceberg salad). The hotel has a very limited room service menu and room service hours. The hotel tower is also motel-like in that the doors to each room exited to the outside, and the hallways ringed an interior courtyard-type area. The venting from the hotel restaurants apparently goes up that interior courtyard, so each day when we left the room we were greeted with different but equally overpowering smells - morning fried bacon, afternoon tempura, evening steak smells. This wasn't a little waft. This was full-on, standing outside a restaurant kitchen vent stink, which was at times a bit nauseating.This next point I make carefully. We are from Seattle, we have traveled and are used to interacting with friends, clients, and other people in the world for whom English is not a first language, and we made the reservation perfectly aware that we were going to a Japanese-owned hotel. We expected many of the staff might speak English as a second (or third, fourth, so on) language, and that in this context we would be the ones with the accents. It was, however, surprisingly and exceedingly difficult to obtain information from some staff members including the gentleman who checked us out, because of a language barrier. He literally could not communicate with us about our questions about the bill, and there was no one else there with whom we could speak at the time. Given the bill we were being asked to sign was in the mid-four figures, and that the hotel is not advertised as being exclusively Japanese, we were surprised that there was not an English-speaking front desk person available when some number of the people checking in or out would, presumably, not be able to speak Japanese.Another front desk staff member was, frankly, rude and not helpful when we (gasp!) wanted information about the 3:30 AM fire alarms that went off one night (Hi, front desk? The fire alarm just went off, and we started to leave but noticed no one else left their rooms. Is there a fire somewhere? Fire alarm - is there a fire? Fire? No fire? If you're sure it wasn't a fire, do you know why the alarm went off? Was the alarm just in our room? Oh, you were testing them? In the middle of the night? Oh, not testing, but resetting them? What does that mean - are the alarms broken? Wait - I hear it on the other side of the hotel now - are you sure there's no fire? Ok, then, can you tell me when the weird residual static noise emanating from the alarm speaker in the ceiling of our room will stop, so we can get some sleep? No? Can you do anything to stop it? No? Ok, thanks, bye).The housekeeping staff did a good job, and the day we checked out we left a tip for them, accordingly.As other reviewers have noted about their rooms, our room (a suite in the "new, renovated" area) smelled strongly of mildew. Given housekeeping seemed to do a good cleaning each day, we could not determine the source of the smell. In the end we opined it was the a/c system, but who knows.The beach in back of the hotel was lovely. We watched the sunset there almost every evening, and the crowd gathered there was a nice mix of locals, others who live on the island, and tourists. I recommend reef shoes if you enter the beach in the middle to the left. The right is more sandy. We swam a bit there, but we snorkeled elsewhere.As others also state, the hotel is on the quiet end of Waikiki. Again, the view from our room was stunning, of the ocean and downtown. However - and this is of course no reflection on the hotel - the jellyfish were visiting our first few days, and because I was anxious to get in the water we actually went and double-stayed one night at the Hilton Hawaiian Village so we could have use of their saltwater lagoon and other pools. At the Hilton we stayed in a tower with its own pool, not far from the lagoons, and paid over $100 less than we did for the New Otani room. For those who haven't visited Waikiki before - the walking distance between the New Otani and the hotels at the top of the strip (Hilton Village, Royal Hawaiian) is around a mile, but in the heat and the humidity and depending on what you are carrying and your level of activity, the walk may or may not be something you are up for multiple times per day. We ended up driving back and forth to visit restaurants, etc. Information about buses and taxis were not readily available at the New Otani. The "travel desk" was most often empty.We tried to borrow or rent one of the paddle boards stored on the side of the hotel. The front desk person couldn't help us, and referred us to the "travel desk," gesturing to the empty table across the lobby. We never ended up in the lobby when the mysterious travel desk person was there, so no paddle board for us. (At least not there; we rented one at the Hilton, $30 for an hour, but it was fun and worth it).The convenience store onsite was a sad, sad step-down from the 39 ABC Stores in Waikiki. We wistfully wished for an ABC Store onsite.(There is no swimming pool - the very good is for the beach onsite).In the end, the view was breathtaking, but the absence of helpful service and enjoyable food options on-site rendered this place an overpriced mistake. If you stay and, as some on Yelp have, can get some super deal where you are paying $150 or less per night, then you might be getting what you pay for. But the postcard view wasn't worth the $400+ per night; this hotel just doesn't offer what you expect when you are paying that much. We will choose more wisely next time, and we won't stay at the New Otani again.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: My experience here was outstanding. The hotel is located directly on the beach, opposite Kapiolani Park, and about a 10 minute walk to the end of the busy Waikiki 'strip'. It's a great choice to avoid the congestion of central Waikiki. There's a wide, uncrowded beach right out of the door. Had a room with dramatic views of the beach and Waikiki. The ground floor restaurant is directly on the beach. Had good food and service. It seems to be quite busy for breakfast, so reservations are a good idea. They offer complimentary beach mats and towels. I'm looking forard to another visit here.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Choosing a hotel to stay at in Honolulu can be an exhausting and frustrating experience. We must have changed our minds every other day. Finally, we agreed to look for a hotel away from the hustle and noise of downtown and stay closer to Diamond Head. After debating over a few locations we chose the New Otani and we could not have been happier that we did.Other than a rather surely man at the front desk who "greeted" our late night arrival, the hotel was everything we could have hoped for. The refurbished rooms with a view of Diamond Head and the Beach were elegantly designed and radiated serenity. The room had a wrap around lanai that was perfect for relaxing with a glass of wine and watching either the ocean or Diamond Head (which loomed over us).. Service was impeccable and the staff were very friendly (except for the night person). Breakfast in the beachfront dining room was a delight. Dinner there was a bit pricey but worth every penny. We also had a very relaxing and delicious dinner at the Japanese restaurant on the second floor. The park across the street is a wonderful place to rest and enjoy watching local activities. Under the shadow of Diamond Head, I sat and watched, among other things, people in yoga classes, high-school students in soccer practice, Frisbee tossing and a volleyball game. t was also nice to sit just outside the hotel and watch the residents go by wheeling their children or, more frequently, doing their daily run.For us, the location was perfect. It was very hot when we were in Honolulu and it is about a 20 minute walk to downtown. We did the walk once and decided we would rather stay around the hotel. I had a bit of a chuckle regarding a remark in a review that one has to walk a bit to find a cup of coffee. We just used the coffee maker and coffee provided in the room.The general area is quiet and we never had any trouble getting a good night's sleep. There is a very well stocked convenience store at the hotel which carried everything from goggles to beer and wineIn sum, this is the hotel I would stay at in Honolulu and would unreservedly recommend to others. .

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: As a former resident of Honolulu I always return to the Kaimana. It is located at the foot of Diamond Head across from Kapiolani Park not in the midst of overbuilt & noisy Waikiki. Yes, they do charge a parking fee because the excellent attendants must constantly rearrange parking due to limited space. This was always done with speed and a smile. My room faced the ocean and insured I could simply listen to the sound of the waves from my lanai not gridlock traffic.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: What a great little Hotel, off of Waikiki. Everyone very pleasant. Rooms very clean, updated with fabulous ocean views. It is right on Waikiki Beach, but yet out of the hustle and bustle. Loved that it is right across from Kapiolani Park, if I wanted to run.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Clean,quiet, inexpensive and the staff are great. The location off the property is off the beaten path. I hear the rooms were recently upgraded. Check out the second floor Japanese Restaurant, which features fantastic food and drinks. Down in the main, airy lobby, you can order a bottle of Kona brew and an appetizer of sashimi all for about $18. Fantastic.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed at the New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel on Oahu from September 23-28, 2012. This was the second leg of our vacation, and the third hotel we stayed at in Hawaii. The hotel is in a great location, right on the beach and next to the Kapiolani Park on the south side of Waikiki. The hotel is also located within walking distance of the Honolulu Aquarium, the Honolulu Zoo, the Waikiki strip, and Diamond Head Crater. The location was ideal for getting around the Honolulu/Waikiki area, as we were on mopeds most of the time. The park next door did house some vagrants and vagabonds, but we never felt unsafe. The location gets 5 stars from me, but that is the best part of the hotel.Our room was in the diamond head wing, which claims to have been recently upgraded/redone, but it didn't feel like it. The room size was average, and had good amenities like a microwave, fridge, and sink. The bathroom was ok. A large vanity area separate from the toilet and shower. The shower was meek at best though. Very little water pressure, and whenever another guest in your wing flushed, the water temperature changed dramatically. The room was mostly clean, but we did have a lot of tiny ants by the front door and in the kitchen area. Big turn-off. Overall I would give the room about two out of five stars.The staff was very friendly and accommadating, and we got beach towels and mats every day. They also were very knowledgable about the area, and informed us of a few great hot spots to visit. There is barley any parking (read: no parking) at the hotel unless you want to valet for 23$ per night. There is a park next door and across the streer that you can park your vehicles at, but it is very crowded during the day, and even spots fill up quick at night. There are also a few shops/businesses located on hotel grounds, but they were pricy. The on-site restaurant also looked very nice, but was very pricy (around 80$ a person for a decent dinner).Overall, this was the better of the two hotels we stayed at while in Oahu, but I probably will stay somewhere else next time.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Stayed there for 4 nights in the Diamond Head view room and enjoyed it. Pros and cons:Pros:Air con goodBed very comfortableBalcony with viewStaff very friendlyQuiet location Cons:Wifi non existentThis is a good hotel if you get a good deal. I would not pay posted rate.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel is located right on the beach (San Souci); no roads to cross! It is a 10 minute walk from the the "Waikiki strip" through Kapiolani Park and is a pleasant walk. We stayed in a "Diamond Head" view room which was comfortable and clean but could use a renovation. I understand that some rooms have been renovated. The Hau Tree Lanai restaurant is fabulous both for the quality of food and the view of the beach and ocean. This is the second time I have stayed there and would stay there again.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: For the most part, I have enjoyed the 4 days staying at the New Otani Kaimana. Of particular importance, was the awesome view from our corner room and San Souci beach just outside the hotel. By far, these were the two aspects worth paying for. The 15 minute walk from the hotel to Waikiki and back, just to get coffee, food, etc, can be a pain though. However, I must say the thing I found most annoying about the hotel was the poor customer service. Having just stayed 4 days earlier at the Modern Hotel at the opposite end of Waikiki, the lack of customer service at the New Otani Kaimana becomes apparent. Franky, the customer service at Teddy's Bigger Burgers was way better.For instance, I did not have my phone with me, so I asked the front desk if they could tell me what the weather was like in Waimea Bay - I was told they did not know. They did not even bother to Google it.Today, I asked if the lounge had a Happy Hour and was told yes, from 2-4 pm. Then, when we showed up at that time and inquired about the Happy Hour, the bartender just shook his head and said not for about 5 years. I stated that a lady at the hotel had told me there was one and he flippantly said "who, the cashier". He was completely dismissive and that is not a way to treat guests.On other item that seems to be guest unfriendly, is the fact that while there is free internet from your room, in order to print your boarding passes, you must use the front lobby computer for a fee of $5 minimum, plus .75 per page to print. What the hell? Isn't the point to be guest friendly and make our stay easier?FYI, I called the Modern Hotel where I had just stayed a few days prior, to thank again the manager for her help while there. In doing so, I complained about this incident and she told me I could come by and print my boarding passes there, if I needed to. Now that is customer service!To be clear, the New Otani Kaimana hotel has a great view of Waikiki, if you get the right room. The beach right outside the hotel is also great, and has an overall calmer environment. However, there are better hotels for less, and they will make your vacation stay with them feel like it matters.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I came here on a 5-day vacation by myself to explore Hawaii. I was very pleased with the overall experience, particularly the service. The valets are friendly and helpful with travel tips, the bartenders likewise courteous, and room service prompt and extremely thorough. The rooms are a bit small and Wi-Fi is very slow, but if you're in Oahu to browse the web in your hotel room you probably aren't reading this to begin with. Besides, at least the Internet is likely to be upgraded at some point.The location is excellent, about a half mile south from the end of the main Waikiki strip (92), ideal for getting a quick warmup on your (my) 4:00 AM walk to downtown. The local beach is perfect for a lively atmosphere away from the downtown area. I have already recommended this place to relatives and acquaintances who are planning a trip to this island. I definitely believe that a reviewer's reputation is at stake for every review posted and I feel confident endorsing this resort as one to consider for a lower cost but still satisfying housing option on vacation here.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: This hotel was one of the best that I ever stayed in anywhere. It is very plush, boutique style with excellent service, restaurant was great and very friendly employees. The hotel is located at the end of the Waikiki beach strip near the zoo and is separated by the park. This gives it a feeling that you have a portion of beach to yourself. The rooms are elegant with beautiful views. The rooms were just renovated before our arrival, very nice job. The only thing that could use improvement was Wi-FI Internet access, I most defiantly will stay here again.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I've been staying at the New Otani Kaimana since 1995 and always have a wonderful time. It's a boutique hotel right on the ocean and is perfect if you're looking for a peaceful vacation on Waikiki but away from the chaos of Waikiki. Things I liked the most: (1) It has valet parking (which you pay for, sadly) so getting in and out with a rental car is really easy. All of Waikiki is congested, but at the New Otani you just drive in and drop off your car in about 30 seconds and you're right there at the hotel entrance. This was very nice after long day trips to Diamondhead or Pearl Harbor. (2) They have a truly wonderful restaurant called the Hau Tree Lanai which is in the top 1% of restaurants I have ever visited in terms of atmosphere and view. You're under this enormous tree in the shade right on the beach. They're very busy, but my trick is to make reservations for 7:00am (right when they open) on OpenTable.com. I am a single traveler and many restaurants have an attitude problem with single diners ("oh hello, loser, no spouse or friends to bring today?") but the people at the Hau Tree were splendid and welcomed me like I was an old friend, and in fact as a single diner I got the best tables in the place. Get the poi pancakes. (3) The rooms with views are expensive, but you get a view of all of Waikiki that is spectacular. (4) Service is great, and there is a little store on the street that has all the food and beach supplies you will need. Things I didn't care for: (1) Bathrooms were small. After you go swimming, you want to shower to get the sand and salt off, and it would be nice to have a big bathroom to move around. (2) It's a fair hike to the main part of Waikiki. You don't want to drive because parking in Waikiki is a pain, but if you walk you're looking at a good 15 minutes or more each way. That's okay once or twice a day, but late at night after a big dinner you may not feel like walking so far. (3) The beach at the New Otani is very quiet. It's near some big condos and this horrible thing called a "natatorium" which is a crumbling cement-walled swimming area on the beach. So the beach area outside the hotel feels confined, and on weekends it can get crowded, although I never felt it was too crowded. But the water is relatively calm, and if you want the bigger waves you need to go to the main part of Waikiki.Overall the things I liked vastly outweighed the things I didn't care for. I visit Hawaii now and then and plan to stay always at the New Otani Kaimana.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I had some trepidation about the hotel from a small minority of reviews, but it was close to perfect for us. We had booked this using miles on United, and we got the cheapest room selection. I had emailed the hotel earlier about upgrading, but thinking we would spend little time inside the room, I decided to not opt for an upgrade.When we checked in, we were pleasantly surprised to get a room on the 8th floor, Diamond Head side, with a narrow view of the Sans Souci beach. The hotel staff were very nice - Chris the bellhop was very helpful with tips. We immediately made reservations for dinner at the Hau Tree Lanai restaurant, and got exactly our desired seating at 6:15pm for the 6:40pm sunset dining. We also ate breakfast the next morning at 7am there, and had drinks one afternoon at the bar overlooking the Hau Tree Lanai. While the dinner was somewhat pricey and strictly from the food perspective not a great value, the ambiance and the service made up for that, and overall it is a great romantic location.The towels and beach mats, and one day even a beach chair, were very helpful. The beach is gorgeous. The location within walking distance of Waikiki beach was amazing! We never had parking issues - usually the valet would ask whether we planned on going out soon again, and park accordingly.The room was small, and the bathroom was also small. But we felt they were adequate. The two things that I wish they would change:1. There should be more electrical outlets in the room - specially near the desk. We had to ask for an extension cord to run from the outlet near the headboard - and once they provided it, it worked fine. But many of the outlets were covered with solid face plates. That does not make sense!2. One day we wanted coffee in the afternoon and went down to the bar. The barman said they would provide coffee maker in the room if we asked for it. Then we also read in the rules that they indeed do so. We got a coffee maker and coffee and cream and sugars, and every day the cleaning person would replenish the supplies. Why is this not standard? For this class of hotel, why do you have to make your guests ask for it?The wind howling across our 8th floor lanai was sometimes too loud, but we got used to it.Overall a very nice find, and we would definitely stay there again!Mahalo.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: "+" - the beach and easy access to it. "-" - rooms need rennovation,noise of the wind and from the yard in the morning. not very attentive staff. stayed for 5 days there and ate in their restaurant only once only because were lucky to get up early that day. to eat there you need to book a table in advance, even for having breakfast. that's not very convenient. parking territory is so small that you have to wait for your turn in taxi.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We've been staying at the New Otani for more than 20 years and it keeps getting better and better.It still has the great location on Sans Souci beach, adjacent to Kapiolani Park. The beach has a good mix of locals and visitors and wonderful swimming in a reef-protected area. And it still has a caring, local staff, many of whom have been there as long as we've been staying there. The bell staff are particularly accommodating with beach Mats, towels and chairs.The Hau Tree Lanai remains a romantic, if somewhat pricey, beachside dining spot and the Sunset Lanai is a quiet place for cocktails and, yes, sunsets.Some things have changed. For the better: The newly renovated Waikiki-view rooms are a welcome improvement, with much-improved bathrooms. There's free wi-fi, something other hotels should adopt. For the worse: there seem to be more tour groups coming to the Hau Tree Lanai, clogging the lobby and making it harder for guests to find space at the restaurant, especially at breakfast.But I'm willing to put up with the occasional tour group. The location, facilities, staff and aloha feel make this the only hotel we would consider staying at in Honolulu.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Compared to the area with the big hotels on Waikiki beach, this seaside location is not crowded and fairly quiet, and it's easy to get in and out of by car. It has a relaxed and "local feel." And while "local" can be good, in Hawaii it can also mean mediocre with a high price. For the $300+/night I spent to accommodate a family of 4, we had an 80's style room overlooking the sidewalk and the parking lot that could definitely have been cleaner. Another party traveling with us was originally assigned to a tiny room with 2 twin beds through which the wind whistled so loudly that they requested to be moved. The staff were very pleasant and upgraded them to a better room. The lobby is looking a little worn out. The food at the Japanese restaurant within is good, although the atmosphere is a bit dated. The Hau Tree serves a very good breakfast, but make a reservation early, because it appears to be a popular stopping spot for Japanese tour buses, and they can get quickly overwhelmed in the morning. The beach is pleasant and quiet. However, if I had to do it over again, I think I'd pay a little more and get a modern, clean, updated room at the Marriott or something comparable. Or, I'd just take my money and spend it on another island, where the beach experience is far better to begin with.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: My favorite hotel in Honolulu.The locations makes it especially if you want a quiet time in honolulu.It is right next to kapiolani park and diamondhead.I would avoid the breakfast and the line is long, but if you have time a great way to spend a few hours.It is a 15-20 minute walk to the main waikiki area.The beach is stunning.The rooms are a bit small if you are used to hotels in Asia, but it is worth it for the view

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: So after our fiasco at the Hilton, we hurried to find a hotel away from the crowds. We ended up at the Otani because they had immediate availability. I will give them credit for that. Here we are, last minute and they fully accomodated us witha room...sort of. Their idea of a room is what us Westerners would call a closet. It was extremely small. My wife and I were tripping over each other trying to unpack our suitcases. Suitcases, which, when unpacked, were stored outside on the balcony. This room barely fit the queen sized bed. The bathroom waa also ill conceived. Small in space, the sink had no storage space and a shower that was nearly impossible to figure out how to work. The balcony overlooked a somewhat quiet beach when compared to the beach down by the Hilton. My only gripe were the number of homeless drunks laying right beneath ourbalcony. This is hardly the hotel's fault however. In a nutshell if you must, for some odd reason, feel the need to go to Waikkiki Beach for the actual beach, and you are traveling alone, the Otani will suffice. Don't expect any towels, pools or any real amenities and do expect a hefty bill for basically a closet sized room. We didn't last one night and opted to check out. The front desk was kind enough to not charge us for a full night, so customer service gets a bump there. Its good in a pinch but definately not a honeymoon destination.
user_name:
Gerard D
Staten Island, New York

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: This is our second visit and the Otani is the perfect place to stay of you don't want the crowds and mall like atmosphere of Waikiki Beach. The rooms are small but elegant and we had wonderful views of both the ocean, all of Waikiki and the surrounding Pali.The food is good and the beach is right outside so you can go for a swim and be back in your room in a second.
user_name:
Stuart L
New Rochelle, New York

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I stayed at the Kaimana Beach hotel when my mom came to Honolulu to visit me. The location is about as close to perfect as you can get. The renovated rooms are tastefully done, and the views are one of a kind, The staff are helpful and full of aloha. The food at the hotel is excellent, but walking to Waikiki is super easy for more options.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We had a very pleasant second stay at the Kaimana Beach Hotel. The staff were extremely helpful, friendly and professional. We enjoyed several light meals in the Sunset Lanai where they serve a good variety of interesting local and international dishes. The beach and ocean outside the hotel are wide, clean and gorgeous with some good snorkelling spots. You'll want to come back. Carol & Patrick

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed at the Kaimana Beach for a staycation weekend with friends and it was fantastic! It's a hidden gem for both visitors to our islands and kamaaina. The hotel has a perfect view of the blue ocean, Waikiki and the fireworks show on Friday nights. We were impressed with the service at the hotel starting from the valet attendant, front desk and the waitstaff in the restaurants. The rooms were clean and recently renovated so it was beautiful. We all had dinner at the Miyako Restaurant and our meal and service there was incredible. There are a lot of Japanese restaurants in Honolulu to choose from but this is now our new favorite place! We had breakfast at the Hau Tree Lanai and how can you not be happy sipping bloody mary's, eating chicken adobo fried rice and eggs benedict under the hau tree overlooking the beach?  I highly recommend this hotel as it is out of the frenetic pace of Waikiki but still a short walk to Waikiki with it's restaurants and shops, the zoo, Diamond Head and the farmer's market at KCC on Saturday's. We will all be back to enjoy another memorable weekend!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: This hotel is near Waikiki but far enough away to be in quiet section down by Diamond Head.Open air lobby & Hau Tree Lanai is a great open to sea restaurant. Great views of downtown Waikiki & Diamond head.our room had balcony overlooking Ocean & Park.Has it;s own beach which was never crowded.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I have stayed at the Kaimana Beach a few times before and keep coming back to it. I love the location, that it is on the edge of Waikiki rather than right in the middle of the hustle and bustle. The views, rooms and service are wonderful! And breakfast at the Hau Tree Lanai is always a special treat to end our stay.We invited some special friends to dinner at the Miyako restaurant and everyone was impressed with the service and food, and unpretentious atmosphere of the restaurant. Sunset on this Friday night was spectacular, not to mention the fireworks as we were seated in a private cabana on the lanai of the restaurant. We all agreed to return again, soon!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Near the great Waikiki beach, far away from the noise, perfect wiew, overall best location for intimate vacation. There was no internet wifi in the rooms :(But the rooms were good, clean with nice balcony and wery good wiew.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: If you want a location far away but close enough/walking distance to the center of Waikiki, this is your hotel. It has its on beach, Sans Souci beach, I believe its called, unlike the other hotels where you have to cross the street and across to the beach. Rooms are bit dated but hey, who cares? It is very quiet and you don't get all the craziness in Waikiki. I walked to and fro every day and the exercise is refreshing. Beach is lovely, too and not crowded.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I was back in Hawaii on business, and I have been returning to the Kaimana Beach Hotel for nearly two decades and before that, when I lived in Hawaii, I used to bring guests there when I was assistant director of a museum in Honolulu. Why? Because it is the best situated hotel in Waikiki in my opinion. It is not a high rise but a comfortable 8 story boutique hotel with a wonderful familial feel to it. No sterile lobbies in which one gets lost. And dining at the Hau Tree Lanai (underneath a more than Century old Hau tree)practically right on the beach is worth the experience alone.  The location is fabulous: it stands as the first building on the far end of Kalakaua Avenue just beyond the Waikiki Aquarium. Therefore, if you get a room on the west side of the hotel (the locals will say the Ewa side) on the upper floors, you will have fantastic and unimpeded views of the ocean, Waikiki, Honolulu, the Waianae Mountains, Kapiolani Park (where the Honolulu Zoo is) and the valleys of the Koolaus in front of which Honolulu is situated. If you are on the other side of the hotel you will have great views of famous Diamond Head. But, even more important is the kindness, attentiveness and the competence of the staff, from the car parkers, to the reception folks, housekeeping, the wait staff, and management. Most of the staff have been around for years and so one knows that they are treated well. And the price is very reasonable for what you get. Obviously I am hooked and I rarely write reviews, but want to share this gem with others.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I stayed at the New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel during a recent business trip to Hawaii after a recommendation from a work contact who is based in Honolulu. I went for the cheapest room option (Moderate) and was given a small room with a view of the parking lot - nothing glamorous and a bit noisy despite being on the fifth floor, as well as dated as other reviewers have mentioned. Amenities are very basic but there's a convenience store around the corner.The hotel location is fantastic if you're there on a holiday trip, though - right at the beach (Sans Souci, nice and quieter than other Waikiki equivalents) and within easy walking distance of attractions including the Aquarium, the Honolulu Zoo and Diamond Head crater, and about 15 minutes from Waikiki proper. I recommend the hike to the crater if you're feeling energetic - it took me three hours in total to walk from the hotel to the summit and back at a decent pace but stopping to take pictures.Service was unexceptional but the two restaurants at the hotel (Hau Tree Lanai and Miyako) were great - do book a table for breakfast if you want beachside seats at Hau Tree Lanai as it can get really busy. The early bird special at Miyako is great value and thoroughly recommended ($28 for a full three-course meal with fabulous views too - book for a window table or terrace cabana).Overall, it was a decent experience for what I paid and I would stay there again, probably paying a bit more for a seaview room.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I was actually quite excited to stay at the New Otani. I've logged over 100 hotel nights in Honolulu at most of the major hotels. This was a business trip that was booked only 2 weeks in advance during the summer, so reservation pickings were a bit slim. It was here or the Ohana East. I chose here. San Souci beach is one of the best beaches on the south shore, and I have always enjoyed sunset dinners at the Hau Tree Lanai, so I thought it was time to check the hotel out. The lobby is dated, but I had read online that they just completed renovating most of the rooms. I booked a Diamond Head view room. Maybe if they would have given me the room I booked, this would have been a different review.Instead, I was "upgraded" to a 1 bedroom in the Diamond Head wing. There are 2 wings to the hotel. The main hotel is a 10ish story high-rise, the Diamond Head wing is a 3 story walk-up. I was told the hotel was completely booked and I had what I reserved a park"ing lot" view. It's not an upgrade just because it's bigger. If you ask for a house in Beverly Hills I don't think the real estate agent would consider a bigger house in Receda an upgrade (thanks Karate Kid for the LA geography lesson). The desk clerk said they would call tomorrow and let me know if they could move me to the main hotel the 2nd night. Never got a call back.The check-in clerk asked the bell clerk to show me to my room. He stepped out onto the front and pointed to the 3rd floor. No ask if I needed help lugging the luggage up the 3 flights of narrow stairs, nothing. The room was big, that's for certain. It's also very dated. If I would have paid about $100 a night less, I would have expected this level of decor, but for the same price as the beachfront hotel, I got a big, old, space overlooking the parking lot. The room is officially a 1 bedroom suite. It had a sitting area with 2 twin daybeds which were uncomfortable to sit on and felt like they would be equally uncomfortable to sleep on. There is also a large table over in the corner taking up space.The kitchenette was actually just a wetbar, refrigerator, and microwave. The bathroom is 2 rooms that cover the entire width of the suite. Everything in the room is dated. Carpet was clean though. It is a large space with no functional purpose. The televisions and TV system was terrible. Channel changing would lag and the picture was not formatted for the screen. The televisions were too small for such a large space. The bed was fairly comfortable, but the headboard was loose, so every time I moved, it shook up against the wall. Hot and cold water were hard to manage in the shower. It is a 2 knob system that requires some precise tuning to get the temperature manageable. Overall, a pretty disappointing visit. I am glad it just lasted only 2 nights. On checkout, the clerk didn't ask how my stay was or really acknowledge anything other than the fact I was leaving. I really wish this would have turned out better. I was looking forward to finding something away from the crowds of Waikiki.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I would agree with all of the previous reviewers comments about where this hotel is located, including how near the bus stop is located - allowing easy access to downtown Honolulu, the outlet mall At Waikele, the airport, Pearl Harbour etc. the view at breakfast was a wonderful way to start the day, and the food and service was excellent. Downside? We arrived in the hotel around 11pm after travelling for 27 hours, tired and very hungry. There was no room service after 9pm, the restaurants were closed as was the convenience store attached to the hotel, there were no coffee making facilities in the room and the vending machines sold only chocolate and soft drinks. If we'd known, we would have been better prepared. Overall, a lovely location and a pleasant place to stay. We would probably go back armed with our own travel kettle.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I recently stayed for 3 nights at the New Otani Hotel which is located just south of the main stretch of Waikiki Beach. My room was on the 8th floor and faced the ocean, which was lovely. Although the room was small, it had been recently upgraded and included a small refrigerator, a safe and a nicely appointed bathroom. My favorite part was the little lanai where I could sit and watch the beach-goers plus stare out to sea. The ocean is really beautiful in front of the hotel and the beach, Sans Souchi, is a nice mix of locals and tourists. Even though I was there on the weekend, it never felt crowded. I walked to the Starbucks every morning, which was great as the short walk takes you through a park, behind the zoo and along the water. The hotel restaurants are quite good and, I thought, reasonably priced. The service was good, the staff friendly and overall this would be my new choice when I have to travel to Honolulu. The clean room and comfortable bed made up for the fact that it was a little cramped. It's unpretentious and I would recommend it for a business traveler as the rooms offer free wi-fi. My nightly rate was $225 - a special offer - but considering the cost of hotels in the area, it was a bargain.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: My family had recently stayed at the New Otani kaimana Beach hotel. It is smaller than those big hotels in waikiki, but it was nice to be away from the crowds. The Zoo, Aquarium, Diamond head is all walking distance and the hotel is right on the beach. Great area for the kids to play and swim. Everyone was always so friendly and very accomodating, and the view from our room was absolutely breathtaking. Hau Tree Lanai was a great place to eat, but recommend making reservations because they are always busy. We all had a wonderful time and would highly recommend this hotel.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The New Otani Hotel is by far the BEST hotel on Oahu. This is the perfect place for a "stay-cation". I've lived on Oahu for 15 years and this is the perfect getaway for my family and I. The hotel is located near Diamond Head on Kaimana Beach at the end of Waikiki. The hotel is walking distance to the Honolulu Aquarium, Kapiolani Park, and all the excitement of Waikiki. The room accomodations are excellent. The rooms are newly remodeled and absolutely gorgeous! We have had the pleasure in staying in a variety of their rooms ( one bedroom apartments, Jr. Suites, Queen Suites). The rooms are very comfortable, clean, and beautifully decorated with ocean and Diamond Head views. The service here is top-notch. From the valet parkers, concierge, front desk, housekeepers, everyone is always so friendly and full of aloha. The restaurants are also my favorites. The Hau Tree Lanai has a delicious Sunday Brunch and breakfast. The Miyako serves Japanese Cuisine. This hotel also has a fitness room, beauty salon, and a mini-market which is so convenient. I can't say enough about The New Otani Hotel. Mahalo for everything. The Ruter Family

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: A sweet hotel in a great location at the end of the tourist strip, close to Diamond Head, right across from Kapiolani Park and right on the beach...comfortable rooms, albeit small, a beautiful restaurant with great views...Highly recommended...

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: This is further down than the main Waikiki beach, but for the cheaper room price than all of those resorts and hotels, you get a clean, nice hotel on the beach! Bus stop is a 2 minute walk; Aquarium and Diamond Head are right there too. Instead of a car, we rented Mopeds and didn't have to pay a parking fee.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed at this hotel the night before and the night of our wedding. To say that our stay at Kaimana Beach Hotel was amazing is an understatement. All the bridesmaids and makeup & hair stylists were in AWE of the view we had from our room! It was absolutely stunning and served as a gorgeous backdrop for our photos before we headed off to the ceremony. The hotel and staff made it difficult for us to want to leave. Even our meals at Hau Tree Lanai were excellent, and we can't wait to recommend Kaimana Beach Hotel to our friends & family who are looking for a place to stay on the islands.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I love this place because it is probably the best deal for a hotel right on the beach in honolulu. It is located in the park a little bit from the end of Waikiki. You can walk to the far end of Waikiki if you need to. The hotel has nice views of the park, beach, ocean, and Diamond Head. The rooms are a little dated but comfortable. There is a refrigerator in the room to store drinks and food. No issues checking in. All parking at hotel is valet parking. You can get towels for the beach near the front desk. In the morning, the beach has a deep shadow from the hotel, but after that it is sunny with very little shade. The water is very calm and doesn't get too deep for a while. The bar inside served the best mai tai that I had on the island. Highly recommended. I usually split time between Ala Moana Hotel and New Otani Hotel when travelling to Honolulu. Highly recommended.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: My wife and I spent 4 nights this past week at the Otani Kaimana. Due to the expense of this trip in total and the exclusivity of the purpose (our 10th anniversary), I booked this trip a year in advance and only after pouring over and over several reviews of just about any Waikiki hotel that had any appeal to start with. First lesson learned.....never overdo reviews. I found good and bad reviews on every hotel, even the most expensive. In the end, it's all someone's opinion and quite frankly, there are alot of misguided soles out there who give poor reviews because of their own lack of foresight into their own bookings. All that said, my wife and I loved this hotel, and we are both hotel managers back on the mainland. Here are the minor things we found and I stress minor as nothing had a negative impact on our stay. We noticed some very small ants had taken up a home behind the PTAC (air conditioner) and every once in awhile, some would pop out underneath, again they were almost microscopic. The door to the bathroom is a louver door and would be better if it were solidly concealing. That is it! What was great?... the room! We had an Oceanview deluxe which gave us a view split between directly toward downtown and the shoreline and ocean - fabulous! I am glad I didn't pay more for a "full frontal" of ocean, absolutely no need for it. The balcony lanais are small but perfect for their purpose of just sitting down and taking in the breezes of which there are many. The bed was ultra comfortable, the room spacious and very clean. Our package which was through Hotwire included and excellent breakfast each day in an awesome outdoor restaurant under the Hua tree. We ate no other meals there other than breakfast. The beach is much better than any of the heavily crowded Waikiki beaches and the hotel even gives complimentary use of beach towels. The lobby area is open to the exterior in the back making it quite breezy but very pleasant. Internet is free (try finding that in other Waikiki hotels) and valet parking which is required is within line if not a tad bit less than most other hotels. The seclusion of this hotel away from the rest of Waikiki is a super plus!!!! Easy walk to town and no sirens, buses, party crowds, garbage trucks etc.!!!! That was a key factor in choosing this hotel. The service including everyone from the room attendants to the valet attendants could not have been friendlier and accommodating although as hotel managers, we really weren't to needy in asking and even the tourist events coordinator which subcontracts space in the hotel but is not operated by the them, was very helpful in our planning of activities including sending us to a fabulous Luau on our last night there (Germaine's). This hotel provided a fabulous experience and I would love to stay again if I every visit Oahu in the future (I think Maui is next though). My compliments and gratitude to all the staff there. And lastly, you can find cheaper places sure, but be wary...Hawaii is a big ticket item - I don't advise scrimping on the hotel room even if you like many others don't plan on spending much time in the room. The bang for the buck at this hotel was awesome.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: This hotel is located about a nice 20 minute walk from the main strip of Waikiki. it is an older hotel, but is clean.The beach of this hotel is worth it. It is very clean and not very crowded. I think that a lot of locals use this beach and they are all very friendly. There isn't much shade at the beach, but there is plenty of places to lay and play. At sunset the residents of the building next to the hotel bring out their beach chairs and chat away. They are all retired and its a very cute sight.The hotel itself is a bit dated, but its clean and the rooms are larger than what you could get on the main strip of waikiki. It is nice to be away from the noise and tourist hussle and bussle. But close enough to walk and enjoy the sights of the strip.The open air lobby is very refreshing. There are nice places to sit and enjoy the island breeze.I will definetly be back

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We really enjoyed this hotel because away from downtown yet a 20 minute walk to Waikki. This hotel was just the change of pace we needed.When you enter the hotel lobby you feel like you walked into a beach paradise. You can see straight through the lobby to the beach. A beautiful Hau Tree acts as a roof. We enjoyed watching the sunrise over Diamond Head and watching the sun set over the beach. The beach was beautiful and located right behind the hotel. There were various coral reefs with an abundance of fish, eels and a couple sea turtles. The hotel provides you with towels, beach mats and surf boards, snorkels and boogie boards are available for rental. Hau Tree Lanai Restaurant provides Breakfast, Lunch and Dinner. We only had the pleasure of eating breakfast here and it was very statisfying. The best Crab Cake we have eaten in our lives.The room we had was standard with a view of Diamond head and the beach. Small but it really didn't matter since we were barely in the room. This hotel was renovating when we stayed there so I can only imagine how great it will be completed.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The location is amazing. Away from the downtown area so you feel more secluded. But it's only a ten minute walk to all the action. The beach is beautiful, very clean and family friendly. Many large parks in the area. Nearly all rooms have beautiful views. Mountain views are breathtaking along with ocean views. We were lucky to have both. The rooms are small and a bit dated but clean and with new flatscreen TVs and comfortable beds. It is being renovated but they are quiet. The staff go out of their way to make you feel welcome. It may not be a ideal spot for a honeymoon but for a trip to have a great time and feel safe and in a clean environment it is perfect. I would come back here anytime and recommend this place to the budget conscious traveler who wants a great location and clean place to sleep.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Liked this hotel a lot for its location,and being small. Nice little beach with easy access for surfing or snorkeling (which is good there). Locals access ocean here, so feels not so touristy. No pool, but who needs it. Being close to Diamond Head & across the streeet from Kapiolani Park, great for morning walks & runs. The rooms are smallish, but adequate. Parking is expensive, but had no problem parking for free in the park area. Parking across the street is free from 6PM - 10AM. Access to highways is not bad either, and you don't have to cross Waikiki. Easy walk to Waikiki, but late at night it feels a little dicey, recommend a cab..

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We have stayed here four times in transit to other islands . We have enjoyed rooms overlooking the wonderful Sans Souci beach and rooms with a view down Waikiki Beach and up the mountains.The hotel is quiet and very friendly. The two restaurants in the hotel are excellent. The Hau Tree Restaurant is a great place for a relaxing breakfast on the edge of the beautiful beach. The Miyako restaurant serves exceptional Japanese cuisine and has a very affordable early bird special with many choices of delicious entree every night. The sunsets views over the beach from the restaurant are spectacular. Walk down the beach towards Waikiki and past the aquarium ,you will find the Queen's Surf Cafe on the beach. This terrific outdoor cafe receives rave reviews from locals. There is live music every night, delicious shrimps and barbecues every weekend.It is great fun to be a part of the local fun in Kapiolani Park, a wonderful place for long walks behind the hotel.There is an excellent convenience store on site.The hotel is well situated for public transportation to many island sites including Hanauma Bay snorkling park, China Town and the public bus that circles the entire island .This hotel is a respite from the crowds and frantic pace of Waikiki but is within easy walking distance of the action . There is a convenient and inexpensive shuttle service to and from the airport.This is not a huge hotel so we always worry that too many good reviews will increase its popularity and make it a challenge to reserve space when we return.Request a renovated room.Our only concern this trip was the noise in the hotel during the day because of the renovations to the ocean front and ocean view rooms.We were there on two occasions, ten days apart and the noise made it difficult to remain in our rooms.During both visits renovations were occurring in nearby rooms despite requests for a quieter location. I am sure that this is a temporary problem but if you plan a visit soon, it would be a good idea to check on the status of the renovations.This is one of the finer places to stay in the Hawaiian Islands and has received many awards for service and location.Highly recommended! The best and most affordable hotel directly on the beach. We hope to return again.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I recently stayed at the New Otani as part of a conference. The hotel was selected for participants specifically because of its location to a great beach. The beach was easy to access, not too crowded and perfect for swimming!Reviewers who said the decor is outdated are correct. The facility is in need of upgrade, which appears to be in progress. I was upgraded to a room with a beautiful view of Diamond Head (no view of water), that was delightful to look at. The nice patio was a plus.The room itself is in need of refurbishment. The bed appeared to be two twin beds pushed together, and there was no work desk in the room. The tub had a hard time draining. However, the room was clean and spacious. Though I would not choose it for a romantic getaway, it was fine for a solo business traveller.The restaurant downstairs under the banyon tree was beautiful, and a great place to start the day. However, if you weren't dining at the restaurant, coffee was hard to come by. The hotel does set out the airpots and small styrophome cups from 6:30am-7:00am, but beyond that time you'll need to leave the hotel. Starbucks (the closest coffee shop) was about a 10 minute walk, each way. The hotel bar stops serving food at 9pm, so this is also an issue if you come back late at night. You'll need to walk into town to find a bite to eat.The staff were friendly, and free beach towels and internet access were real plusses, too.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Really like this hotel. Easily walkable to Waikiki but quiet and away from the hustle & bustle. Rooms small but remodeled ones are really nice. Very clean & a friendly staff.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Perfect hotel for us. Ok it was a bit of a walk to waikiki main town but at least you are out of the hustle and bustle. Nothing but the sound of the waves from your balcony doors. Only took 15 minutes to walk and it felt very safe. My husband and I would definitely go back and really enjoyed our honeymoon.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I stayed at New Otani for four nights in April 2012. Below are pros and cons:Pros:(1) Since it's a bit away from the center of Waikiki (see Cons No. 1), although the hotel is located on the beach, it's significantly cheaper than other hotels located close to the center of Waikiki beach.(2) It's literally on the beach. Since the hotel is smallish, you really feel that the hotel is on the beach (I think you don't feel that way in a big hotel on the beach because the main building of the hotel is not as close to the beach as this one)(3) Therefore, it's quiet. The beach in front of the hotel has a feel of a private beach (of course, there is no private beach in Honolulu)(4) If you drive out of Honolulu, it's convenient, because you can avoid crazy traffic of the central part of Waikiki.(5) Has a bit of a "boutique" feel (although it's hard for me to call it boutique). Sort of similar to smallish hotels in the Mediterranean. Cozy and personal.(6) Staff are all nice and friendly.(7) You can get beach towel and beach mattress for free and go to the beach.(8) It's next to a park, and a lot of local Hawaiian are having fun (BBQ, sports...) in the park. So you can feel less touristic.(9) Room is clean albeit not new, and spacious (for Honolulu standard). Equipped with a decent-sized balcony.(10) There is a morning coffee service at the front desk (but they close it very early...)(11) Close to the Diamond Head. You can actually walk or run there.Cons(1) FAR AWAY from the center of Waikiki!!!! You need to talk 10 minutes (possibly 15 if you don't walk fast) to get to the nearest bar (except for the one at the hotel) or ABC store (there is a small convenience store at the hotel but there's no comparison to ABC). To the center of Waikiki (let's say Moana Surf Rider), you need to walk 25-30 minutes. And the public transportation is limited (there seems to be a bus but it seems that the bus runs not very frequently). And ladies might not want to walk at night to the hotel (there's a big park, and it's sort of quiet/dark).(2) I was cheap and chose the cheapest room, which is located in the Annex. Annex has only three floors and not facing directly to the sea. People in the park nearby can see the inside of the room. Annex is significantly worse than the main building I think.All in all, I think it's a great deal, if you don't mind the distance. I recommend paying a bit more (you save a lot by choosing this hotel!) and get a high-floor room in the main building with ocean view. Since the main building is so close to the beach, it must feel good!!!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: My husband and I stayed here for 5 days. Some rooms in the hotel are currently being refurbished but we knew about it beforehand. The location of the hotel is fantastic, walking distance to Waikiki (10-15min) in a very peaceful and quiet area next to Kapiolani park. I haven't rated the hotel with 5 stars due to the small room size, lack of kettle/coffee machine in the room, very small bath towels and the refurbishment works which theoretically start daily at 9am but in practice you can start hearing the noise from 7:30am. Everything else exceeded our expectations (cleanliness, comfy bed, new decor, L'occitane toiletries...). The staff is very friendly. Upon our arrival we were given a room on the third floor. We booked an Ocean Superior room but could only see palm trees out of the window so asked at reception whether they could give us another room and we were relocated to the 8th floor which had the Ocean view we were dreaming about. The hotel has a helpdesk with a very friendly person who provides you with as much information as you need about places to visit, activities to do during your stay, etc. The hotel has a parking area ($23/day) but if you don't want to pay the daily rate you could safely park your car on the street (there's plenty of free parking on the opposite side of Kapiolani park). If you rent a car through the hotel's website beware that the prize doesn't include the compulsory car insurance ($35-$80 per day!!). There's a small convenience store next to the hotel (for which there's a one off 10% discount for the hotel guests) and direct access to the beach. The New Otani Kaimana is very good value for your money. Recommended!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The new Otani is in the perfect location in Waikiki! Walking distance to the main attractionsand minutes to Diamonhead. Visit the Waikiki aquarium or Kapiolani park across the street. It lies right on the water and has rooms with great views!! While it is a little olderthe location, views, bar & restuarant are wonderful. We asked for a microwave which wasperfect for a quick oatmeal breakfast along with the coffee and fridge in the room. Staffwas always available when needed. The beach front is a common place for many local swimmers and we often saw many turtles swimming right in front of the hotel. Plentyof snorkleing right in your own little beach!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We visited the New Otani because my boyfriend had wonderful memories of staying there many times before...he couldn't wait to return. Boy, was he shocked and stunned! The room was so small' we didn't have anywhere to put our two suitcases...nasty old tile and grout in the small bathroom. The old louvered door to the bath was layered with dust and old grime. Ick...we were unable to upgrade after trying, trying, trying....so we left after two nights. Be careful! The pictures on their website don't show any of the nasty old rooms...they only photograph the renovated suites. The restaurant breakfast and service was excellent.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Nestled in the foothill of Diamondhead and literally within the confines of the Kaplolani Park with it's ancient banyon trees and multitude of birds ,it's hard to believe this oasis is just a 5 minute walk away from world class shopping, restaurants, cultural and sporting opportunities galore. The staff is Japanese, precise and service oriented. Our room(#614) was spotlessly clean with beautiful ocean and mountain views.there is a fridge, iron, ironing board, robes, extra pillows for the asking and a coffee pot, which you should request as soon as you arrive.closet and drawer space is cleverly designed which made unpacking a snap. This is our third trip to Hawaii and it was definitely the most relaxing and fun.... It's all about location, location, location, which this place has in spades. If i could change one thing I would have asked for room617 which has a wrap around lanai, but what the hay, we spent most of our time outdoor on the secluded beach(which does have a life guard) ( beach mats and towels are in the lobby, free for the asking, we usually had the beach to ourselves! Nirvana!!!!!or venturing forth toward Kalakaua avenue via the beachfront flagstone and mortar esplanade that connects the beachfront to the commercial center of Honalulu. It's wide enough to accommodate both a slow lookie lookie or a fast calorie burner. Beautiful either way.we stopped for lunch at the Sheridan Waikiki (rum fire terrace bar) but it was way too frantic With kids running roughshot over their harried parents . We just squeezed our hands, finished our Mai Tais and returned to our Otani ..... Don't miss brunch in the Hau tree Lanai, a favorite of discerning locals. Make a reservation to avoid disappointment!!!!! Do stay on the 6 Th floor or higher for the most glorious views. You will be so glad you have discovered this gem!!!!!!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The pictures look NOTHING like the rooms -at least not the standard rooms. The rooms were "new" in the 70's maybe but definitely nothing modern about them now. We asked the front desk if there was another, renovated room and he was rude and sarcastic. There were leftover hairs in the bathroom, we could hear our neighbors TV, alarm clock and conversations through the walls - not their fault. The walls are just that thin.If I could do it over, I would have selected a more affordable place downtown. Hope this helps!
user_name:
Autumn G G
Redondo Beach ca

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: This hotel is hidden gem. Its the best location, has the best beach and is across the street from the largest park in Honolulu. Its quiet and not crowded like off of Waikiki. The hotel is on the beach and has better rates than the big box hotels on Waikiki that arent even on the beach. Big sandy beach with Life Guards. Reefs for snorkeling. Best area to do lap swimming as reefs are located in one area so it makes for a better swimming beach as well. Lots of access to the water with boats, kayaks, paddle boards etc. Next to the aquarium, zoo, park and only 5 minutes from downtown shops. Very nice restaurant as well. If I come back to Honolulu I will stay here every time. I like that its not crowded. Great beach for families and very nice staff here as well.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: My husband and I live on Oahu and spent a weekend at the New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel. Everyone from the front desk to housekeeping were friendly and made sure we were having a nice experience. The junior suite Ocean view room was clean and the view of the park, ocean, sunset and Waikiki was great! Dinner at the Hau Tree Lanai was superb! We had the prix fixe dinner and the portions were huge, presentation beautiful and everything was delicious! Reid, our waiter was attentive and made the evening fun. We will definitely return for another relaxing stay-cation!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The hotel was excellent but I would not recommend the moderate rooms....No view and very small...we upgraded to a suite and were very happy...If you like a quiet , small hotel in a lovely area then this is your choice...The food is excellent, although expensive and the staff at the hotel is friendly and good. We will come back.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Thank you, Otani Kaimana. We had the time of our lives there. We want to come back for our 5th anniversary. Cant wait to be there again. Aloha!Axel and Aida Foerster

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed in the lower building with the fridge, sink, and Microwave so we could make lunches or breakfast, altho' the Lanai HauTree restaurant is delicious. We were so close to the beach, had a gorgeous view of the park, bay and Waikiki in the distance. We did not have to listen to bands playing and drunken crowds as did others who stayed in the crowded Waikiki area. The hike to town by beachwalk or street to catch the expedition buses took about 20 minutes, usually in the dark of early morning. The street people sleeping in the park or on sidewalks were harmless, there is no crime. The hotel provides beachmats, towels & umbrellas. The staff are so polite & helpful; hotel is very clean & the beach & swimming area just a few steps away, was great, with surfing, kayaking, snorkling, etc. I will stay here again.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: My husband & I were in Honolulu for 8 days on business and booked ourselves into the Halekulani which is a very upscale elegant hotel in Waikiki. The first two days there was no hot water in the hotel, some boiler problem and we felt the management did not properly respond to our concerns so we moved to the New Otani which was approximately half the cost. We were delighted we changed. The Halekulani is definitely fancier and more elegant but in many ways the New Otani was much more to our taste. Being enclosed in buildings and people in Waikiki is not our style so we appreciated the distance. One could still walk there or take the bus if needed. To us an important part of the Hawaii experience is the beach and the New Otani sits right on an excellent beach with good swimming. The hotel has beach towels, mats, chairs, and flippers available. We booked an ocean view deluxe room which hung out over the beach. The floor to ceiling windows and sliding glass doors provided a wrap-around view of the ocean and Waikiki. From the lanai we could also see Diamond Head. We loved it so much we chose to have breakfast and cocktails on our lanai rather than in the restaurant which can get crowded and what could be more romantic than that stunning view. The food was very good; many local people come to the charming outdoor restaurant for breakfast, lunch, and dinner occasions. The hotel could use some sprucing up as it is a bit dated in decor but it certainly made up for it in location and views. And, there was hot water!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Overall this is a good hotel but there are some buts. The first problem is that this hotel is somewhat away from Waikiki so you really need a car to get around. On the other hand this hotel is really close to the beach. In fact it is on the beach so it's easy to go for your early morning or evening swim. Breakfast is served in a lovely open air terrace filled with shady trees. The problem is that there aren't enough seats to accommodate all guests and opens only at 7 am so you either book in advance or you will queue for a loooong time. The hotel is getting a bit dated and will probably need a bit of TLC some time soon. But overall a nice hotel for a restful hoilday. Prices are a bit on the high side but this is Honolulu.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: This was my first trip to Hawaii and it was perfect! The hotel has a fantastic restaurant with a wonderful breakfast daily. Be sure to make a reservation for breakfast. It can be very busy... It has beautiful views of the ocean, as well as Diamond Head. The location is ideal because it is within walking distance of Waikiki, yet, it is not crowded or loud. The beach area is beautiful with a variety of activities. I simply cannot say enough about the location and price. For such an expensive destination, the price for staying at this hotel was more than ideal. We did park our rental car in the park at night, basically, right outside of our sliding glass door, and didn't have to pay for parking. Do be careful where you park in Honolulu though... We were towed our very first night there (out of a parking garage) because we had no idea we were parking on private property. That was our mistake.... However, that has nothing to do with this lovely and quaint hotel. The service was excellent and I look forward to staying here again in the future.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We booked a Diamond Head Room and were upgraded to the Diamond Head Junior Suite when we arrived. Gorgeous view of the mountain as well as a partial view of the ocean. Staff was very friendly (except for one trip advisor downstairs) and the service was impeccable. The room was cleaned every day and the bed turned down every night. The food was amazing in the main resturant, although a little pricey. The drinks were strong but great as you watched the sunset. Also, the hotel is located on the best beach in Waikiki and no pool is needed. Location was great since it's far enough away from downtown that you can fall asleep to the ocean but close enough to walk to go to any bar, resturant or other hotel. I would recommend this hotel to anyone and plan on staying again!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel is a medium-rise, dated, sleepy, limited-service, unglamorous hotel that is set on a beautiful beach on the quiet, Diamond Head end of the Waikiki strip -- and it is enchanting. Rooms are small, there is no pool, common areas are minimal, and the "gym" is a vendor-operated bare-bones facility, but the service is relaxed and attentive, the whole place oozes with a friendly island vibe, and the hotel's setting on the low-key Sans Souci beach could not be more perfect. It's a great home-base for a Hawaiian vacation, for the location manages to feel quiet and beach-y, yet it is within walking distance of the bustle of Waikiki, and an easy drive to Oahu's top restaurants, attractions, shopping centers, cultural institutions (which are few in number), and outdoor options. If you want to park yourself at your hotel during your visit to Honolulu, go to another place with more amenities, but if you want a comforting place to rest your head in a welcoming and clean, island-style establishment, there is nothing else quite like this place. I highly recommend it.
user_name:
travelerhnl
New York City, New York

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We were upgraded to a partial ocean view unit that was actually a corner unit. The blue ocean and wonderful sea breeze lulled me to sleep. The sound of the waves throughout the night was soothing and very relaxing. We joined friends for Sunday brunch at the Hau Tree Lanai restaurant and I enjoyed my Crab Benedict with lots of coffee. This stay-cation was much needed. Mahalo to the helpful staff and very courteous valet employees. We will return!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: There is no pool, but you are right on the best swimming beach in Waikiki. However, the hotel itself feels tired and dated. Louvered door to the bathroom was rather embarrassing when sharing a room with a friend. Overall, not worth the money

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed here for four nights in the run-up to Christmas. It has a great location right on the quiet Sans Souci beach, and a history of having had Robert Louis Stephenson to stay. It is on the site of an old family house, although all that seems to remain is the great verandah. The staff are nice, and the hotel is genuinely pleasant, while being something more than a dreadful modern concrete block. it is also conveniently located - a short, easy bus ride from town. The rooms were small but workable. The big problem, at least for a non American, is the air conditioning, Hawaii has a pleasant winter climate, trade winds, nice night time breezes, no need for fans however if you open the window you are assailed by the sound of a hundred whirring machines, it sounds as though you are at the end of a runway with a plane preparing to take off.
