So that leaves you with little choice but to swelter inside your own room with windows shut or to put on the dreaded machine in your own room. No wonder the US's carbon foot-print is appalling.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: This is my favorite hotel to stay at while on Oahu, which I visit at least once a year. The beach in front of the hotel is beautiful, but away from all of the hustle and bustle of Waikiki, which is about a 15 minute walk away (a very beautiful stroll along the ocean!). Our room had a spectacular view of beach and the Waikiki coastline. It was so peaceful and relaxing to wake up to the sounds of the palm trees outside our window and we love, love, LOVED being able to just head downstairs and straight onto the beach!! Note: Definitely try out their restaurant on the ground floor, which features a delicious brunch on a terrace right on the beach!!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: If you don't mind walking to the "main drag" this is the spot. Since the hotel is away from the main area, the beach seems private. This hotel offers a waterfront hotel, with a inland price. You can literally exit th hotel and step on the beach (and go swimming). We had a dimond head view and were on like the 13th floor. We loved our room, very nice & clean. Bed was comfy and the room had a flat screen TV which was nice when we wanted to get away from the beach. The quarters seemed very private.The hotel offers delicious food. The Restaurant is on the water and we ate there three times, because it was, honestly, better than the other restaurants we tried. Another benefit is that it is easy to get in your car and drive because it's on the outskirts of town, giving easy on and off freeway access. We loved this hotel and can't wait until we can afford a trip to Hawaii so we can visit again.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I love this charming boutique hotel overlooking the park at the quiet end of Waikiki. My first stay here was in 1975. It's a tad expensive compared to 1975, but you can usually get upgraded when you arrive for a reasonable price. Our room was 817, on the corner with a panoramic view of the ocean, the park, and the distant tall buildings (especially gorgeous at night!) Be sure to ask for a renovated room. Rooms are small, but just what we wanted as a couple. The food in the Hau Tree Lanai Restaurant is superb, and we have been there many times--one of our favorites on Oahu. For us, this hotel is the best, and we will return.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: And a world away in ambiance. No bachelor parties here. The bar closes around 10 and the Hau Tree Lanai is where longtime Honolulu residents mark special occasions. The rooms are clean if a bit dated, the service is great, and there's a sweet locals beach, with a lovely reef for snorkeling and turtle-seeking. Out front, there's all of Kapiolani Park, and great running opps. You can valet park in the lot, park at the meters for free between 6PM and 10AM, or around the far periphery of the park free for extended periods. And you can walk to The Aquarium, the zoo, and Waikiki. No swimming pool, but the beach is kid-friendly.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: This is THE place to stay if you are a fan/supporter/sweats holder for a Honolulu Marathon runner. It is right at the 26 mile mark of the marathon course, and it makes a great place to watch the race and to crawl back to after the finish. The Lanai Restaurant has a superb corned beef hash for breakfast ($17 or so), and the coffee is OK and the staff refill attentively.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We have stayed here several times now on transits through Hawaii. This hotel is about a 10 minute walk from the chaos of Waikiki, making it quite most nights. On the recent trip we had a free upgrade to a one-bedroom suite. While the decor remains a little dated compared to some other Waikiki resorts, the price is right and the hotel is right on a spectacular spot of beach that is much quieter than the main beach - indeed it seems to be the spot the locals seek out to swim.The restaurant is excellent (not cheap though) and adding breakfast to the room for $10 is a great deal for couples. Staff is always really courteous and helpful. One great perk is that they will give guests access to a room to clean up on your last day there - most hotels push you out at noon, but most flights west are at night. The New Otani on more than one occasion has given us a room for an hour (usually after 3 pm so they can see what is free) to let us clean up from walking around on our last day and prior to heading to the airport....free of charge. It means you can check out and get them to hold your bags, then go shopping, for lunch or to the beach for the afternoon and then come back and freshen up prior to heading to the airport....a great perk for guests.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Hotel is a perfect distance away from the mob at Waikiki-about a 10 min. walk. Beautiful to see the city lights from your balcony and walk to enjoy a mai tai at the Royal Hawaiian but far enough away to escape the cacophony. Splurge and get an ocean view room, as opposed to a garden or park view. Cost is not prohibitive and wonderful to go to see the sunset and listen to the waves while falling asleep at night. Also hotel is walking distance from some great local eateries, like the Diamondhead Market and Grill. Granted, we enjoy walking and this morning excursion might be too much for some. We also ran the "Diamondhead Loop" every morning which starts right outside the hotel's entrance. If the opportunity presents itself, we will be returning.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Nice hotel great breakfast on the beach, room was big enough for two, just, however the room was very clean and comfortable. Location was 10 minute walk from Waikiki so not far from the main beach however at night, walking back not all the streetlights were working so was a bit dark. Great little private beach if you like space from away from crowds, and you could get beach towels and hire snorkel which saved buying them.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: If you want to have a quiet place in Waikiki, location is excellent and the beach is in the front of the Hotel. It's too bad that they don't really renovate their rooms. Wallpaper is dirty and fixed pillow and foot cover had food stain and dirty and kept making up room without cleaning. When turn the faucet it makes noises and sink was damaged and walls are paper thin. No coffee maker in the room. Restaurant is great and people there are very nice. It will be a great place if they can update their room.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I've stayed many times at this beachfront boutique hotel at the end of Waikiki / where Diamond Head begins. On the plus side it's beachfront, reasonable, and quiet in a great location ( if you want to be out of the main congested tourist area). On the negative side, I've had several bad experiences here, including food poisoning . Also the rooms are very nice but very small , but after all you're in Hawaii , how much time do you plan on hanging out in your room? I should also mention that this is a Japanese owned property and the headquarters are in Japan- should you encounter a problem - you are out of luck. Having said that I would still recommend this hotel. Aloha!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We loved the location of the New Otani. The 10-minute walk to the main Waikiki strip was easy enough, yet far enough away from all the activity to make the hotel seem a little more relaxed. Being right on the beach was a bonus. The room was small and a little worn, but very clean and comfortable enough. We were parking lot side ... some reviews say to avoid that side, but it gave us a little look at the beach and a great view of Diamond Head from the balcony which was nice. We'd stay there again.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We have been to this hotel in the past and loved its location( righ ton the sand). We had a garden view room, with A PEEK a boo view of the beach, but it was so close! our room was smALL, but well appointed. The closet and bathroom are seperated by a sliding door, and it was very close to the bed, but it sis not matter to us. we packed just a little and spent most of our time on the go, THE staff was very friendly abd the fact that the hotel restaurant was on the sand made up for it not being the most polished in surroundings. The decor was very Hawaiian, and comfortable. The prices were amazingly competative.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The location and proce for this hotel (summer rate of 190/night) seemed like a good price, but I stayed in the section overlooking the park with microwave and fridge and it was definitely dated. The fridge was a nice bonus, but I didn't use the microwave like I had hoped. Parking is valet only even though the lot is ridiculously small. The restaurants on site are pricey, but the hotel bar has good food and great staff! Patty, Lori and the regulars were great at providing suggestions on sites to see, places to eat and importantly, places to avoid. Overall, a so-so place, just dont be surprised if your room isnt as modern as the lobby.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: If you want a quiet hotel, then this one is for you. It has been a great hotel to stay, but it has become very expensive as of late. The room rates have gone up considerably and the rooms are getting a bit tired. Breakfast is fabulous on the lanai, but is overpriced especially $5 for a cup of coffee.I used to love this hotel, but now, not so much. Great location, but really getting too expensive.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: During our fist trip to Hawaii, I researched extensively, and was pleased with the reviews this hotel received. Upon staying there, I am only more satisifed. As soon as we pulled up, saw the koi pond, enormous open lobby, and restaurant literally on the beach, I thought, "We're really in Hawaii!!" Sure, the rooms are not enormous and the hotel would benefit from an undating, but come one, you're staying in Hawaii right on the beach! The balcony was wonderful, we could see 2 different slices of ocean view, as well as Diamond Head. The location is the best part of this hotel though, perfectly close enough to Waikiki to enjoy the hustle and chaos if you so desire, but far enough away to be quieter. Absolutely gorgeous view of Waikiki from the beach right outside your room. Our first night we were invited for a manager's welcome, with fruity drinks and delicious appetizers. We also took advantage of renting beach chairs, so handy. You can easily walk to ABC stores, park, movie on the beach, etc. LOVED IT!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The location of this hotel is great. It's situated on a a nice beach. That is where the great ends. The rooms are domicile small. It looks like it might have been nice in the early 60's, but it's time for a BIG update and simply putting on new bed spreads isn't going to help. It feels dingy and depressing. I checked out after one night. They were nice enough to offer me an upgrade when I mentioned checking out (which in no way was a threat for an upgrade). By that time I had moved three times because they kept giving us rooms with one bed. I had requested two beds because I was traveling with my son. I had already found a new hotel that I knew was a winner, so they could have offered me a suite and I was still getting out of there! I would advise looking elsewhere!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I had a room on the 7th floor with a view of the ocean and this hotel might be the best kept secret in Honolulu. I've stayed at the big hotels up the road and this hotel has just as good, if not better, service, great L'Occitane bath amenities, and its own under-utilized beach. It's a great value for the money and was very comfortable and clean. This hotel also has a great restaurant right on the beach (separated by a very low wall). Great for evening dining.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We were lucky to get one of the remodelled rooms, and it was gorgeous. The hotel is right on the beach and is a 5 minute (not even) walk to the hustle and bustle of Honolulu. The room was prisitine and the staff was helpful at every turn. The only complaint was the room size for the price. (Although I do tend to err on the cheap side). Beach towels and mats were provided by the hotel and the front desk staff were very helpful with sightseeing tips. Even the restaurant was amazing! I would definitely recommend!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: great hotel,only place we stay anymore in waikiki.its quiet,no ck in lines,on beach,and on street parking max $4 a day.very clean,rooms are a little small,but who cares.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: A few of us stayed at the New Otani over a weekend between meetings and it was fine. We had a suite that faced the park side (much better than the parking lot side) in the older part of the hotel. I would hope the newly renovated rooms are nicer than the one we had but for the price, the amenities were great (fridge, microwave, two convertible beds in the LR) and the location is terrific. Waikiki can get so loud that being on the Diamond Head is nice if you're not into late night action. We didn't eat at the hotel - there are lots of places to eat local food towards Kaimuki that we enjoyed.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: What an amazing location and staff. Our room on the 5th floor had a wrap around balcony so we had views shore break waves, Waikiki and Diamond Head. Not the most expensive category either. The staff at the hotel were beyond helpful, giving info on restaurants, beaches, the bus system and more. The restaurants in the hotel are extremely overpriced so we ventured out. the hotel is situated walking distance, across the park, from the melee of Waikiki so you can join the throngs of tourists and then walk back to the little oasis that is the Otani. The rooms were spacious, clean and very well equipped. (ask for a coffee pot) Even turn down service with flowers on your pillow. You'll want to pick up a book or camera and sit out on the balcony and just watch the people, surf and clouds. Palm trees are at eye level and you feel like you are up in a tree house.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed 5 nights and the first thing we'd like to share is that the hotel's staff was beyond expectations. We asked and were upgraded at the first opportunity and at reasonable cost to the ocean view room. If we ever asked for towels, toiletries, or to arrange any sightseeing - everythings was done right away and without further reminders. So rare nowadays! The rooms are older but clean and have everything you need including a small fridge and a coffee maker (if you ask). The location is 10 out of 10 - 10 min to the all the action but in a quiet and green area. The beach is 10 out of 10 - excellent snorkelling - go in the morning. We even saw an octopus! The service is 10 out 10 - see above. If we go back - we will only stay at the New Otani. Big Thanks to the hotel staff for our great experience.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed at the New Otani for 14 nights and did not have a complaint. The room was small, but when you are in Hawaii you should not be spending much time there. Basically used for a shower after being on the beach all afternoon and then to sleep. The room however was very comfortable and clean and had been renovated in the past year. If you are going, book a oceanview superior or oceanfront. We had booked a moderate room and then decided to upgrade. Atsuko gave us a great upgrade deal (thank you Atsuko for all your help). We loved it. Had breakfast in the restaurant a few times (fabulous) and even saw and spoke to Richard Chamberlain a few times. This hotel is in a very quiet part of the city, which we loved. The beach here is fantastic, in fact we didn't set foot on Waikiki beach until our last day there. Great food is just a few steps away from the hotel at a little place called the Queen's Surf Cafe and Lanai. Great homemade food and coffee's. Kait makes this place fantastic. They have surf and turf buffet every friday night for between 25.00 and 29.00 per plate. This includes live music and a great place to watch the sunset and the fireworks. Trust me you don't want to miss this place. The New Otani is only a 10 to 15 minute walk to the heart of Waikiki. Great place, great people. Loved it, loved it, loved it. Thanks all for such a great trip and memories.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Stayed three nights in October 2011. Fantastic room view from ninth floor corner overlooking Diamond Head and Waikiki... The room itself was in need of a remodel as all the fixtures were worn, carpet dirty, furniture aged etc. With a complete remodel this would easily be the nicest hotel in Waikiki! Great location past the zoo with a great walk to the shops and restaurants of the Waikiki strip.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Yes, the rooms can be just a bit seedy--OK more than a little bit seedy--badly stained carpet this most recent time. And on the small side. But I wouldn't stay anywhere else in Honolulu.That's because:1) The location can't be beat. It's on the coolest beach on that side of the island. Great swimming (in fact, there's kind of a little swimming course out to a wind-sock and back that's fun, challenging, and a favorite of locals as well,) good snorkeling. You can learn to surf nearby. It's a 15-minute walk from Waikiki so you have the option of immersing yourself in the riff-raff or keeping away if you want to.2) The staff can't be beat. I think it's telling that in the 10 years or so I've been coming to this hotel the staff turnover has been almost zero. The super friendly super helpful faces you see time and time again range from the parking valet, to the front desk staff, to the people who book touristy stuff...3) The value is good...c'mon...where else are you going to get a decent beachfront hotel for $135 a night or ocean view for $240? Also, the in-room amenities are excellent. And the public areas of the hotel are pristine.So, in this case, I'm willing to overlook a slightly musty room, or a badly stained carpet in favor of what always ends up being a very positive experience.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Visited the New Otani recently for our honeymoon from Perth, Aus. Great hotel value for money. No flashy stuff like the big hotels - everything you need though. Pleasant stay. We got to the hotel well before our check in and they accommodated to us with no issues even upgrading us to a better room for no extra $ :) Only fault was issue with incorrect card payment though hotel management apologised & rectified it immediately.Hire a stand up board while you are there and head out to the flag - easier than you may think and good fun!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Just returned from a week's stay at the New Otani Kaimana Beach hotel, had a brilliant stay, small boutique hotel which means more intimate than the huge chain hotels. We had a room around side of hotel, side views of both Diamond Head and Beach. Our room was compact and comfortable but clean and well maintaned, while the room was great it would certainly be worth paying that bit extra for an ocean view. The hotel staff were all friendly, polite and helpful, we had some great trips around the island which the travel/trip desk were great in helping us organise.The hotel is ideally situated if you want a personal feel hotel away from the hustle and bustle of Honolulu while equally still within 10mins stroll from the city, we walked through the adjoining park into the city every day/night and felt totally safe.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: This hotel was a bit dated, but loved the staff, the location and the restauant. If we came back we certainly would consider this hotel. Again the staff was as a good as any hotel we have stayed in on vacation or business. We stayed two times during our Hawaii vacation and enjoyed both times.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed here for 4 nights in early September. Our room was a Deluxe Ocean View on the 4th floor for $240/night + $23/day parking before a 13% tax. While not much wider than the king bed, it had reasonable floor space between the foot of the bed & small table & chairs. The dresser & refrigerator were tucked into the wall along the walkways. The vanity area was small but well-laid out. The bathroom was tiny & you had to step into the tub to close the door to sit on the toilet. We slept well on one of the most comfortable king beds we've ever encountered. The sheets & cover were of excellent quality too.The view was a good one for a room that was not the top location & pricing. The balcony was just deep enough for us to sit at an angle. Our complaints center around the number of inconveniences we encountered & a consistent, uniform attitude of indifference from various staff. 1. Restaurant service was mediocre & the loud music from the bar's crooner made communications with wait-staff & each other a bit of a challenge. 2. None of their restaurants were open when we wanted an early lunch at 11am - despite late breakfasters who lingered there - or an early dinner a different day. Even the bar wouldn't serve food at those times.3. Reservations were needed for the primary dining room for ALL meals due to its small size. 4. Something was happening at the park the hotel borders every day. This meant speakers blaring from 7:30am until 10pm. On vacation we like to sleep in or wake up slow.5. We had to call housekeeping to the room two nights due to a malfunctioning stopper in the tub. 6. Since its a small hotel with a tiny lobby, there's no place to hang out & enjoy the view if you don't want to be on the beach itself or in your room.I'd chosen this location to get away from the noisiness of the Waikiki hotels per TripAdvisor reviewers. In hindsight, the availability of dining (& shopping) choices within easy walking distance of those Waikiki hotels presented an opportunity to save money on overpriced restaurant food & apply those savings to staying at a swankier hotel high enough up to get away from their version of noisy. Plus no boredom!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: A world apart from those crazy Waikiki strip hotels on a quiet beach surrounded by parkland. Free parking across the street is convenient, as is the handy and affordable 24-hour convenience store near the lobby entrance. We arrived late on a busy Saturday and were originally given a tiny room with two plush twins vs the requested King. The somwhat confused front desk offered to remake the room within the hour - we politely requested another room and got twice the space and a real King overlooking the park. It was quiet enough to sleep with the patio door open which was wonderful. The next morning we skipped the somewhat chi-chi restaurant, checked out, and headed west for a round the island road trip. As we were headed back home on a late flight, we asked for a late check-out but were surprisingly offered a hospitality room later in the afternoon for a shower and change before the flight. Nice ! The free in-room internet worked after some persistance with choosing the right "New Otani" access point. Wired service was also available. Nice 40" flat screen TV and plush linens. Not the biggest of rooms but comfortable and tropical. Happy to return anytime !

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We had to go to Honolulu for a medical appointment so only stayed one night but chose this hotel because we'd heard good things about it and wanted to try it out. We had an ocean view superior room which I understand is one of the rooms that has recently been totally renovated. The room was decorated nicely and cozy as well as clean.. We had a queen size bed that was comfortable and one chair and a table The closet held a luggage stand as well as a small table top ironing board and iron. The bathroom was tiny but had all we needed including L'Occitane amenities. A small refrigerator, a decent size flat screen t.v., and a very nice balcony with seating for two rounded it off. The a.c. worked fine. Because it is a smaller hotel no room is a long walk from the elevator. Check in and out was friendly and efficient and there were no long lines. This hotel is right on Sans Souci Beach, only steps from the hotel. which makes for some pretty good sight seeing from the restaurant, the bar or our balcony. There is a life guard station right there and yet the beach is not crowded at all - like it is just up the way on Kuhio or Waikiki beaches. If you want to be close to that this is not necessarily the place, but otherwise it's great. Also there are some small shops in the building but if you want to be within walking didstance of Waikiki Shopping this isn't it. Valet parking is the only option and at $25/night seemed like a lot, but we always got our car IMMEDIATELY - no long wait, and felt that it was in a very safe lot. The Hau Tree Inn is in this hotel and serves an excellent if mildly pricey breakfast. We look forward to trying the Japanese restaurant on the top floor of the hotel. Also, if you have reciprocal privileges, The Outrigger Canoe Club is two doors away. We'll definitely stay here again.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: This was my first trip to Hawaii and stayed at The New Otani on the Diamond Head part of Waikiki. It's an older "boutique" hotel and a bit worn. My room was very small but recently remodeled and did have a great view of the ocean. Private beach was nice and not roo crowded. The restaurant - Hau Lau Tree had great food.Overall it still felt like just OK. NOT geared for the business traveler at all. Only WIFI in the room and no printing capability. Service was pleasant but did not go out of their way to feel particularly special.If you want to get away from the masses of Waikiki in a little quieter part, this is a good choice.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: This hotel is at the base of Diamond Head, on the edge of Waikiki, on the beach and has the "Greatest Out Door Restaurant" in Hawaii. Located just off the hotel lobby, the service is remarkable, the food is exquisite and they serve the best "Kona" coffee in the world.Visit this restaurant once and you will have to come back. This is the perfect place to eat breakfast if you want to experience what is is to feel special.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The New Otani is on the SE side of Waikiki Beach in the shadow of Diamond Head and across the street from Kapi`olani Park. I booked it because it is QUIET, away from the crowds and hubbub of Waikiki but close enough to walk there if you want to. It has a first rate restaurant right on the beach for breakfast (try the eggs benedict), lunch and dinner. However, the restaurant is a bit pricey, so most of the time, I jumped in my rental car and made for the cheap places on Kapahulu Avenue which runs makai-mauka from the ocean to the H1 freeway. There is parking across the street, free from 7 PM to 10 AM. Outside of those hours, you must feed the meter at 50 cents an hour. And watch out, those meters are carefully monitored and a major source of city revenue at $35 a ticket. Valet parking at the hotel is $23 a day.The Diamond Head side rooms are tiny--just room enough to walk around the twin beds and really no provision for suitcases (mine, empty, would not fit under the bed). With two people in the room, it's a bit crowded. The place is clean and the staff friendly. There is a cool-ish refrigerator for drinks and leis and a safe. For beverages and ice, you must visit the 8th floor.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Wonderful location short 10 min walk to the shopping and bars. I'm so glad we were away from the busyness of the beach and loudness of the city. We found free parking most of the days otherwise the meters were cheap compared to the $20 parking the hotel charges. We stayed in the moderate room which was very outdated and small we did not get the free upgrade we inquired about it but the upgraded rooms were also outdated and not worth the money. Please check out the moderate room pics which were not listed on the website we booked on. The restaurant was very good but expensive

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: My wife and I stayed at the New Otani Kaimana Beach hotel for a week. The location was just far enough out of the mayhem of Waikiki to feel like we were on a different island but yet close enough for us to walk to it when we were hungry. This being said they have a not too expensive ( considering where you are at) great outdoor dining deal , right on the beach, that we ate at least one meal at a day. Tons of space on the beach in front of the hotel and there is a convenience store attached to the hotel that we bought snacks and sunscreen at. We liked this place very much. You will too. You also don't really need a car here, but its up to you.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: If you want to wake up to the quiet, serene sound of the beach this is the hotel for you. This is the first hotel on the south side of Kapiolani park, ON the beach.Perfect hotel for travlers who want to wake up peacefully after a quiet nights sleep, get in rental car and drive around Oahu, come back to hotel, hit the beach for evening swim then go to bed.If you have been to Waikiki then you know how crowded it is (nothing like Magnum PI). On my second trip there I decided to get a quieter hotel. If you need the noise, bars, dance clubs, thousands of people just outside your window this is NOT the place for you. This hotel has 2 sections, Main building has smaller rooms but they are closer to the beach, better for couples. The annex of this hotel is couple of hundred feet from the beach these are like mini apartments with kitchens, this is probably better for families.some Hints:In the early morning and early evening you can find FREE parking along Kapiolani park (pay attention to the signs). If not then pay for the $23 hotel parking.If you get a rental car, buy a cheap cooler at some store, fill it with drinks, booze and snacks, you can take in to hotel room and use as mini fridge. You can rent snorkeling gear at the hotel for better prices than anywhere else.Some WARNINGS:Hotel does not offer breakfast, the on site restaraunt is for dinner only. (to be fair very few Waikiki hotels offer breakfast) So you will be walking to Dukes or get into car and drive to some breakfast joint away from the beach.Bring your walking shoes, if you want to walk to the restaraunts, stores on the other side of the park it is about 0.5mi walk each way. Also the park has beach bums living on it, they usually sell Leis made with real flowers about 5 bucks each, on corner of Kapahulu and Kalakaua.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed in a recently renovated ocean front corner room. The renovated rooms are very nice. Absolutely loved the sliding glass door on each of the corner walls! We would leave both doors open all night to hear the ocean. The location is great next to the park though it is a bit of a walk to the shops & other restaurants. I would definately stay here again.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Our very first impression of this place was negative - stepped out of the taxi to be asked by the bell boy, " do you need help with your bags?". We had about 8 bags, most of them heavy... of course we needed help!! Check in was smooth enough but then we got to the room. Oh my... the most depressing place I've seen since back in the days when I had to stay in cheap business hotels in Tokyo. The "moderate" room is to be avoided at all costs. They are tiny little coffins fitted out with functional but ugly furniture with no colour at all. Bland, tasteless, musty, old, pukey. The aircon smelled so we had to turn it off. Bathroom plastic and tiny. Our room was the second from the beach so although no direct sea view, we could see the big blue from the balcony - which by the way was about 30cm wide and for the most part looked out onto a parking lot. For us, the killer was that the internet was dodgy (worked sometimes, other times not), was not wifi and it is impossible to connect more than one computer at a time. That was a deal breaker for us, as we run a business and have to keep up with emails etc at night (plus research the rest of our trip). To their credit, they let us cancel the rest of our stay without any charge even though we had already paid for the entire stay.We did have breakfast at the Hau Tree Lanai and it was pleasant, although the food (like all food in Hawaii it seems) was not all that healthy and left us feeling heavy and tired. There was no services attached to the hotel either - no laundry, internal spa, fitness center, amenities - very basic indeed and totally overpriced. We didn't even like the beach that much, as there were no waves to catch, so it was kind of more like a swimming pool. Certainly not what you come to Hawaii for. Well, not us, anyway.We're in another hotel now which was half the price and is 100 times better. Glad we bit the bullet and moved.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Loved this place.Located off the main strip of Honolulu in Diamond head, its got almost a private beach.The best snorkeling is right in front and the restaurant is five star all the way.My wife and I will stay again if ever in oahu.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The New Otani is clean, cool and the staff is so nice. Love the restuarant and they have the best breakfast in the world, right next to the sand. The beach is nice, the rooms are clean and the ocean view Jr. Suite was awesome. Coming back every year.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The hotel is located at the very end of Waikiki beach, in a very quiet section with a park to the side and front, an amazing view of Diamond Head, another older looking hotel to the other side and the beach at the rear. This hotel is very small and dated, but it is beachfront property at an extremely low price (atleast tha'st what I paid). The fact that there is NO POOL and NO BEACH SERVICE, did not bother us because we live in Miami Beach. The hotel was just a place to bathe and sleep, so theonly things that were important to us were that the beds were very comfortable and everything was clean. The easy access to the metered parking accross the street was also very convenient (no money needed after 6pm but always make sure you have quarters anytime prior. We spent our days sightseeing, so it wasnt a problem. Oh by the way, if you are from a warm climate, the water here is very cold and the chill in the wind does not help. At night it is very chilling so you made want to wear a little sweater over your cute summer dresses : ( IF HOTEL AMMENETIES AND SERVICE ARE IMPORTANT TO YOU, STAY AT THE WAIKIKI OUTRRIGGER OR THE HAWAIIAN VILLAGE.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed at The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel for 4 nights while in Hawaii for our wedding. First impression of the rooms was that they were small. But after talking to random people staying other places we learned that most rooms in Hawaii are not very big. Over all the hotel was beautiful, clean, and very quite. It is located on the quite side of town but within walking distance of shopping, eating, and surfing. The service was excellent and the hosts and hostesses are friendly. We got some what of a price break for being a wedding couple along with an room upgrade. We loved it and plan to return for out 5 year anniversary. :)

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I was looking for a one night stay in the Honolulu area at a decent rate (for Honolulu) via Hotwire, and ended up at the New Otani for about half the rack rate. We did get one of the small, older rooms mentioned in the other reviews but I had no complaints given the rate. The room was clean, the air conditioner worked great and we had a nice view of Diamond Head. I liked how the hotel was just outside the hustle of Waikiki, but yet close enough to walk. It was also very easy to find, which was a relief considering the network of one-way streets in the area. The valet parking (no self parking) was $23.00 but there is free parking along the nearby park as long as you move it by 10 AM (read the signs). We did not eat any meals at the hotel.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I discovered this small-ish hotel when I ate at its restaurant, the Hau Tree. So I knew that the location is great and that it has access to a wonderful, and (for Waikiki) fairly quiet beach. Usually I stay at the Royal Hawaiian, but this time I decided to try something quieter and cheaper.The stay began well -- they upgraded me to an ocean view suite despite it being the Fourth of July weekend. The Otani Suite is a corner room on a high floor. From one balcony, you get a view of the ocean and from the other a very close-up view of Diamond Head. You can't get much better than that in Waikiki.In my opinion, the quieter location and the fact that you can get such a great view for a reasonable price compensates for the hotel's flaws. The biggest downside is that parts of the hotel haven't been renovated in a while. My suite seemed semi-renovated. Clearly, some parts of it had recently been refreshed, but the bathroom retained its 1980s-style fixtures (gold-plated faucets!) and a jacuzzi tub that's seen better days. I liked the fact that the hotel is very open, so you exit the rooms into an outdoor hallway. But from that angle, it looks little better than a motel. Still, the hotel grew on me. Even though it was touristy, there was something laid-back about it that I liked. And of course the Hau Tree restaurant is worth at least a couple of visits!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I stayed in this hotel in September 2010, and wrote a review at that time. I again stayed in this hotel in room 612 in July of 2011. And, my opinion is basically the same. There are good and bad points to this hotel.We had requested room 812 where we stayed last trip. However, the hotel did not accomodate that request, and moved us two floors lower. Basically the same exact room, so not sure why our request could not be granted...but, oh well...same great view.With investment, this could be a premiere property. The beautiful San Souci beach is one of the best in Waikiki. Being away from the hustle and bustle of the main strip is a plus, but being just a short walk from that action, is also a plus. The rooms are clean. There are some minor updates done to the rooms, but they are still very dated. Our bathroom this time had pink and green wall paper, a gold-colored flush knob on the toilet, yet other fixtures were chrome. So, the place needs some TLC and cohesiveness. The shower did not have much pressure, yet the tub still drained slowly. But, still we had an amazing view of the ocean, so who spends their time staring at the dated wallpaper anyway?Last time I commented about how quiet my room was. This time, not so much. When our neighbors had their t.v. on, it sounded like it was coming from our room! Luckily, they turned it off by 10, and we did not hear any other sounds.The guy that checked us in was friendly, helpful and had a smile on his face. Our maid the same. However, all other staff we came in contact with, barely made eye contact, or could produce a smile. No one was rude, yet very few were overly pleasant.Again, we faced homeless people in the park. This time, two begged for money. But, we never felt threatened.On, July 4th, they ran out of beach towels... minor inconvenience. Ate at the hotel's Miyako restaurant...again, fantastic food and service. Yet, the place still looks like a cheap Chinese Restaurant off of the interstate, (albeit, with a beautiful view of the ocean),The thing that got me the most this time, was when I started comparing prices. We had Mai-Tai's at the hotel's bar. $11.00 per drink! That's right, $11.00!!! Yet, when we had Mai-Tai's at Dukes Canoe Club, they were $7.50. At Hula's $5.00!We bought a 750ML bottle of Sky Vodka at an ABC store...it was $17.95. However, at the hotel's convenience store, this same 750ML bottle was $22.95! One banana, they sold for .79cents. One banana!So, it seems the hotel is taking advantage of the fact that you are so far from other facilities, so they gouge you on their prices...because they know it is a 10 minute walk for you to buy elsewhere. While this may be the capitalist way, because there is no near competition, it seems wrong to gouge your customers choosing to stay in your hotel. I met a local, who referred to the hotel's convenience store as "shopping at Tiffany's" because their prices are so inflated!Anyway, after 5 trips to Honolulu and looking for a hotel with an ocean view room.... this is still the best hotel I can find at this price range. Unless research or suggestions come up with other viable alternatives, I will return again to this hotel upon my next trip. Tip for next trip: Avoid the convenience store, and make a trip to Safeway to stock up on toiletries, snacks and drinks. Do not patronize the hotel bar, as their prices are inflated. Forget about the appearance of the room and homeless people, and focus on the beauty of the ocean! So, the front desk does not make eye contact, or smile...as long as they are not rude...who cares...you are in Hawaii afterall!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The New Otani Kaimana is a great hotel in a great spot with reasonable rates in an otherwise expensive city. It's just a short walk to the strip in Waikiki but far enough away that you don't feel like you're in the city. The hotel is an older building that's been renovated so the rooms are a little small but they're clean and comfortable with great built in storage and spacious lanais. It's not a luxury property but it's got a boutique atmosphere with nice amenities and who needs a pool with the beach just out your door? The restaurant and lounge serve great food and drinks, we were able to sit in the lounge and order from the full restaurant menu. Kaimana (Sans souci) beach is right out front and it's a lovely beach; small and off the beaten path, it attracts both tourists and locals who go out for morning and evening swims. The hotel provides complimentary beach mats and towels and the Friday night fireworks display in Honolulu is spectacular viewed from the beach. There's a laundry facility on-site, the building boasts two fast elevators and the staff are friendly and responsive. Parking is valet only, there is metered parking across the street at the park but we opted for the convenient valet at $20/day which is actually a good deal on the island. The stroll down the beach walk along the water to Waikiki passes by one of the local parks, a beautifully kept park where locals barbecue and sunbathe. Other reviewers mentioned homeless people in the park and there is a small contingent of them but we always felt comfortable. I'd be cautious walking through most any park at night and this was no exception, however, walking by the park on either the beach or street side at all hours felt safe, with lots of people always out and about and walking around too. The New Otani Kaimana is close to Diamond Head and easy to navigate to other destinations on the same side of the island. Overall, the hotel is a great deal, especially if you book in advance, we'd stay there again in a heartbeat.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed here in December for our wedding and absolutely loved it. The beach out the front is nice and quiet compared to the busier Waikiki options which are just a short walk away if you really want it.. Great garden restaurant. Our suite gave us both ocean, city and mountain views.Would love to go back to Oahu and would have no problems staying at the New Otani again.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Great location for our needs. Walking distance to all of Waikiki. Kaimana Beach was very nice....not as crowded as Waikiki. Nice public park adjacent to hotel. Some rooms are in dire need of updating. Oceanview rooms were nicely appointed but rooms on the other side were definitely not! We were with a large group & everyone paid the same room rate....

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed here on our honeymoon. Fantastic quiet location off the strip but still a ten minute walk to everything. The hotel is beachfront and has gorgeous views of diamond head. Great staff, clean rooms. The only negative I could think of is that the decor is outdated, but we didn't spend our time in the room. The restaurant Miyako was astounding and the service was impeccable. If you stay at the hotel, make sure you go to the Japanese restaurant and get the prix fixe.
user_name:
arisu00
New York City, New York

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: This is a very good choice for a hotel near Waikiki, but away from the congestion, and near Diamond Head. We were just a few stories up, with palm trees at the window, with a Waikiki view. We were pleased. You can walk past the adjacent park into Waikiki for dinner, shopping, etc. There is another very large park across the road from the hotel. It's all actually more lovely than I expected.With that said, some cons are as follows. The hotel needs renovation, which I think is now underway. Our room was comfortable enough, but needed updating. The bathroom toilet had a slatted door, ok but not necessarily private. (Housekeeping was good, though, with a tiny orchid placed on each pillow for turn-down service.) There is a lounge and restaurant adjacent to the lobby; the restaurant is ocean-front. We considered eating there once but turned away due to the extremely loud live music there--just way too much.More pros: The concierge and those at the lobby desk were helpful. Valet parking is expensive, but valets were quick and helpful. There are two washing machines and two dryers on ground level outside the hotel, which is a great idea if you want to pack lightly and wash clothes on your own. There is a store there also that sells very high quality beachwear. There is also a hair salon.If you want to find an inexpensive and local place to eat, try driving down Monsarrat Avenue. There are several sandwich places there, as well as a Coffee Bean & Tea Leaf. Bogart's eatery--very casual and hip--has breakfast and lunch selections. If you need a walk-in haircut (for male and female), try Paul's Professional Barber, on Monsarrat Ave., also.I would recommend. I would stay here again.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: This hotel is looked on the other side of the park that boarders Waikiki. The noise and tourist craziness of Waikiki is left behind, yet all is within walking distance. The service was great and the staff very friendly. We paid for a Diamond Head view room which includes a view of the parking lot...hmmm. Wouldn't bother to do that again. We had friends in a "moderate" room. Their balcony overlooked the park and their room was larger than ours. We'd definitely choose that room instead. Our room also had slow drains in the sink and tub. One downside to the hotel is the parking is valet only to the tune of $20 a night.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed here for two weeks and everything was perfect. The food in the restaurant is excellent, we ate most of our meals here. The service is good and the employees are friendly. Our room had an nice view of the ocean, everything worked the way it should and the bed was comfortable. The location of the hotel is far enough from Waikiki Beach that you can escape the crowds, but when you want to party, play and shop you can walk to downtown Honolulu. This is a great boutique hotel, we will stay here everytime we return to Hawaii.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Stayed here for business on April 26-28th, middle of the week. The hotel was not full. My 6th floor room was tiny and dumpy. Seriously, it looked like a Motel 6 room and had a small balcony which overlooked a parking lot. The bed was full size, not queen and the bedding was old and worn, like the rest of the room. The sink, single, made a horrible noise when you turned the water on and the air conditioner also made a racket. I called down and asked for a more newly renovated room, something 1980's circa, at least. They offered to move me, for an additional $80. So, I tried to stick it out but the first night, the air conditioner was so loud that it woke me often and I finally went down to the desk to complain at around 4:30 a.m. The guy said they didn't have another room in my category, his words, but offered to move me, for an additional $140. Seriously? The customer service was absolutely horrible. The front desk folks seemed to care less whether you enjoyed your stay or were comfortable. The real kicker was, I had asked a local colleague to stay at this hotel, as well, so that we could work. She's a local and got a rate that was $60 less than mine and her room was completely renovated. Unbelievable. Everywhere in their lobby you see the trip advisor sign and logo, so they're very proud of their reviews. On another note, the bar and restaurant were great and the guy selling the shell necklaces in the lobby was very kind.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The New Otani Kaimana was a letdown; we have stayed at their property in Beijing, which was fantastic. However, the Kaimana located at the end of the beach disappointed at almost every turn. From the check in where the desk was unable or unwilling to provide information on the local bus routes, to the Parkview room with dead bugs in the bathroom. One of the biggest disappointments was the lack of beach front sitting, except for the restaurant, which was beautiful but only open at meal times, no pool or lanai...nothing! The hotel is quiet, but there are other, nicer properties in the same area.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: On earlier visits to O'ahu, I've stayed at the enormous 'chain' hotels; all usually quite good but massive and impersonal and with a jaded staff. The New Otani is very highly to be recommended:- the location is wonderfully restful at the eastern end of Kapiolani Park, as it were exactly 'under' Diamond Head Crater. Thus it's far from the noise and traffic of the main drags of Waikiki. It's right on the beach and has perhaps the best one of Waikiki. Indeed, it's about 20 minutes walk from the nightly high life of Waikiki... but if you're not into that kind of thing...- the service is absolutely impeccable and more: it's downright friendly, efficient and helpful. The hotel is quite moderately sized compared to the Chain Palaces, and the staff quickly know you by name and inclination.- my room - a single - was kept spic-and-span. Though the furniture was a bit 'dated' and 'tired', everything functioned very well. Though a 'cheap' deal, my room's pleasant balcony even had some sea-view. Excellent light-occluding curtains; and all electronics one might wish.- the in-house restaurant Hau Tree Lanai serves amazingly delicious breakfasts; and as far as I can judge the 'up-scale' Miyako Japanese Restaurant has got to be one of the very best in town. My dinner was absolutely superb.Highly recommended for service, location, and in-house services!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Stayed here for the second time (first was more than 15 years ago!) Location near Diamond Head is very nice if you want the quiet end of the beach, as we did. A little hard to find through Waikiki's one-way traffic grid if you arrive after dark! We reserved the basic room but were upgraded to an efficiency room in the annex, which had the advantage of cooking facilities (minimal) and a partial ocean view but the disadvantage of stairs. On balance, it was very good. The annex rooms were comfortable & everything worked, but could use a little updating. I'd recommend this for a short to medium stay on Oahu, but if you're planning a long visit you're probably better off renting a condo. I'd return again on a short-stay basis. Oh, and the Hau Tree restaurant is really good, especially for breakfast. Try the seafood omelet.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Stayed at this wonderful hotel the end of December and beginning of January for 12 nights. We had our 16 yr. old grandson in the room next to us. The staff are so special to us and our family. Wonderful, helpful and so accomodating. My husband and I are returning again this June w.o. grandchildren to try one of the renovated rooms. Seems like the New Otani is the only place we go anymore. We always know we will be well taken care of and greeted with that special "Aloha" spirit. Thanks New Otani, keep up the great work. Also, a special thank you to all of you at the Hau Tree Lani. Can't wait for my french toast with macadamia nuts breakfast every morning.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I have been going here since my first trip to Hawaii in 1995 and never looked at another hotel. Although amenities have reduced and, for some reason, the New Otani Club management back in Japan have decided it's better business to charge club members more than the occasional stayer, there is no doubt that this remains a gem on the periphery of the craziness of Waikiki. Local management has been stable, promotions are made from within existing staff and everyone is treated like family. Indeed, the words I hear each time I ull up in the cab for another visit, I hear "Welcome home"" Ah, yes.................
user_name:
sumobaba
New York City, New York

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Booked last-minute to escape the blackouts in Tokyo. The location is very nice -- a short walk to central Waikiki Beach, but far enough away to avoid all the commotion. The adjacent beach is public but very quiet.That said, this hotel is nowhere near the service and amenities offered by the New Otani hotels in Japan. The "annex" rooms, which are usually the cheapest, are outside walk-ups accessible only by a well-hidden staircase. We purchased a special rate which included "free breakfast," but this was actually just a voucher for a very slim continental breakfast in the on-site restaurant. On our first morning there, there was a rain shower early in the morning which closed half of the restaurant -- apparently for want of a mop -- and led to an hour-long wait for breakfast. The rooms are old and in slow decay, though they have upgraded the TVs since some of the other critical posts were made on this site.All in all, a pretty good deal for Waikiki Beach, but you get what you pay for.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The staff was very friendly and helpful and remembered me by name(a bit of a shock)My father and i booked a double room, (through expedia)when we arrived we were told there were no double room in the hotel. so we ended up with a king and a roll-away bed. not the best way to sleep for the price we paid, but the room was very clean, and quite small.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Dates of stay: 2/9/11-2/14/11. We have been staying at the New Otani every one or two years for over 20 years because of its quiet location remote from the noise of Waikiki. In contrast to Waikiki, one can leave the windows open to let in ocean breezes at night. Other pluses are free parking in the park adjacent to the hotel, location on Sans Souci Beach, and a responsive and efficient staff. However, on our most recent trip these pluses were outweighed by several negatives. There are no nearby places to eat – the coffee shop at the hotel closed a few years ago - and the hotel restaurant is comparatively pricey. We stayed in a moderate (economy) category room, which was tiny and badly in need of refurbishing. The built-in furniture was in shoddy condition, the carpeting was old, the sliding doors to the balcony were difficult to open and close, the sink stopper did not work, and the view was blocked by a highrise building almost within touching distance. A coffee maker that we requested from housekeeping was filled with ants! We'll probably stay here again, but only if the room has been refurbished.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: My wife and I have stayed at the New Otani twice, the first time with our then-teenage son, and the second time (Feb 2011) with our infant grandson. For us, the location was great: right down the street from my elderly mother who we were visiting. On our first stay, we booked a junior suite. The room was well past its prime and not as clean as we'd have liked. The level of service was all over the map. Our best experience was at the lobby-level restaurant, where most (but not all) of the waiters, bus-people, etc. were warm and cordial, especially those of Polynesian descent. Least satisfactory were the front desk staff, who were haughty and irritable. We left feeling no desire to return.Several years later, we came back anyway because the location is so convenient for us personally. We will never go back again. Our travel agent booked us into the hotel annex because the main building was full. She was not told that there was no elevator. I checked the hotel's website and it does mention that the rooms are walk-up, though in small and easily-missed print. On arrival we were told that we had a third-story walk-up or nothing. We decided to brave it, and for four days we hauled our 22-pound grandson and all his gear (not to mention our own) up and down three floors. I imagine we could have found someplace in Waikiki with an elevator to take us, but at the time, with the little guy's best behavior starting to unravel, keeping the New Otani room seemed like the right call.  Just as before, most of the restaurant staff were delightful, particularly the Polynesians. And as before, the front desk staff was not very nice (with one exception). Again, our room was dowdy and not very clean. And the room configuration was weird: one had to stand in the middle of the room just below the bottom of the bed to watch the television. (We are not TV viewers so this did not bother us.) The shower mechanism was full of moving parts that never seemed to work together right. And just our luck, the employee and guest smoking area was right underneath our room, with a prevailing onshore wind -- right past our room. As a result, hanging out on the porch with our grandson (who needs clean air) was not always possible.Something I saw during our first visit but hadn't really thought about was the hotel's cultural orientation. New Otani is a Japanese brand that Japanese tourists look for when the travel overseas, as many Americans look for Hilton or Marriott when they travel abroad. The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel caters to Japanese nationals, many of whom come as part of a tour. On our recent stay, I observed the hotel staff's interaction with the Japanese more carefully, and noticed that the staff seemed more friendly to them. I did not see a single Japanese in the hotel annex, slogging up stairs with luggage. I had the distinct impression that at the New Otani, it's Japanese first and haole second.I suppose this is understandable. Japanese tourists visit en masse, bringing a volume of revenue no business could really ignore. And it only natural that the hotel reaches out to its bread and butter clientele. It's the business the New Otani is in -- I can't expect it to change to suit my family's needs. But not being Japanese, we won't be staying there again.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Indeed everyone raves about the location of this hotel. It is far enough away from the noisy crowds, but close enough that you can walk to everything you need in Waikiki. However, for the price they charge, I expected MUCH more. The room was quite tiny and the door to the bathroom has slats in it that did not close all the way (i.e. the door was not solid). So when you were doing your business, everyone could hear you quite clearly. The sink area was small and cheap with flaking wallpaper and stained countertops. The walls were chipped too. Very tacky. The beds were comfy though!!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Although not in the heart of Waikiki, I love this location. It's a long walk to Waikiki, but it is walkable and it's a nice walk. And it's far enough away from Waikiki that it's not full of crazy partying tourists. There's a nice little beach right there and it's across the street from Kapiolani Park and just down the street from the zoo, aquarium, and Diamond Head. The only drawback I'd say is that some of the rooms are kind of small and cramped, but out of the many times I've stayed there, I've only had one room that was too small. The other times I've gotten upgraded to a huge suite. Ask for Tararat when you check in, she is extremely nice and helpful! Once when I stayed there, I was walking down to Diamond Head to go boogie boarding and a parking lot attendant stopped me to give me a ride on his own personal scooter! That's how cool they are here, it makes for a very nice stay.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Located just minutes from Waikik this little gem of a hotel is located between the beach on one side and Kaiman Park across the street on the other. If you want the hustle bustle of Waikik you can catch the #2 bus just yards from the front door or transfer to other busses for a trip around the island. The hotel staff is friendly, helpful and quite professional. The gem of a restaurant is totally picturesque and tranquil. If you want to be surrounded by restaurants, tourists, this is not the place for you. But if you want the balance of being able to visit the city but not be absorbed by it, this place is perfect.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We just had another wonderful two-week stay at the New Otani this past Nov., (our 5th time back), and plan to return again soon. There isn't enough space to say all the good things I'd like to say, so here's a brief recap...The hotel is at the far end of the Waikiki beach and Kapiolani Park, just on the other side of the Honolulu Aquarium (a must see). It's an enjoyable half-mile walk to the downtown area for shopping, restaurants, nightlife, etc... and then it's back to the peace and quiet of the New Otani..... we call it the best location in Honolulu. I should add that we are well acquainted with major hotels all over the world, so we have some basis when we say that the entire staff at the New Otani is tops for service, friendliness, and helpfulness. As for the hotel itself, it is not a large-box hotel like some of the major chains. This is simply a wonderful, quaint Island hotel that you would want or expect in this environment. While their bar & lounge area is small, the adjoining outdoor restaurant (Hau Tree Lanai), which touches the beach, is superb for breakfast, lunch or a romantic dinner. Even the locals frequent this spot. So, when not viewing the sights of Hawaii, our favorite morning activity is sitting outside for breakfast, having Kona coffee, reading the newspaper, and enjoying one of their delicious breakfasts…all while gazing out at the sands, only a few feet away….and that’s what I call paradise.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: This hotel is aproximately 1/2 block from downtown Waikiki. A short 10 minute walk away from the crowds of Waikiki Beach and business district. There is a wonderful aquarium right in between that should be toured by all.The hotel itself is very nice, the views wonderful. We stayed in a 'partial ocean view' room and had a great view of the ocean as well as downtown.The staff was very attentive and catered to our needs immediately. There are parking fees, we parked at the park next door free of charge and it was a safe place to leave the car.All in all, a great place to stay if you don't want to be in the busy area.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed at the New Otani for six nights in the middle of November of 2010. It is a medium-sized hotel RIGHT ON San Souci Beach, a 15 minute walk from the central Waikiki Strip. The decor is old-fashioned, but delightfully so. There is a small fish pond in the front, and the elevator looks like an elevator should look in a classy beachside hotel from the 70s. As with the rest of Hawaii, there are a lot of "open-air" spaces incorporated into the architecture. There is a fish pond at the front of the hotel, and a convenience store, as well as a few shops. This is useful because the nearest ABC (convenience store found ALL OVER Waikiki) is a ten minute walk away, through a large park. The quality of the room depends on which one you get, although there is a lanai (balcony) in every room. Some of the rooms are quite small and have a view of... their parking lot, or the hotel next to it. But if you are lucky, there are also some beautiful rooms and suites overlooking diamond head, or the ocean. We were in a Jr Suite where EVERY ceiling-to-floor window faced the ocean. It was stunning. There is complete and easy access to San Souci beach, and the concierge will even assign free towels and beach mats for hotel guests. The restaurants in the hotel were fancy and this was reflected in their pricing. The staff were friendly and helpful, and we were very pleased with our stay and were sad to leave.We would definitely go back.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: The service was wonderful and the location overlooking all of Waikiki, the park and Diamond head were beautiful particularly at sunset. Breakfast at the Hau Tree on the beach was wonderful. It is a great value. Everone is helpful and the spa, Japanese style ,is very nice.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: My husband and I stayed at this hotel because we wanted something close by to Waikiki without actually being on Waikiki. We were upgraded to an ocean view room for free which surprisingly, had a view of the ocean. The room was very clean and very quiet, and although it looked like it had been updated recently you could still tell in spots that it was an older hotel. I loved that it was right on the beach (no crossing the street for us!) and the beach was a little protected so we could snorkel and not worry about big waves and surfers. The only downside was that to get to Waikiki, you have to walk past a park which while beautiful in the day, is home to a few homeless and can make for some uncomfortable walks at night. But really, that was the only downside. If you're looking for a good value right on the beach with a bit slower pace than Waikiki, this is probably a good bet for you.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We booked a moderate room for one night. The room itself was small, very old, and the bedding wasn't the greatest (pillows were lumpy)--and it really didn't look as nice as the one they have in their picutre. Our room was one of those rooms that could adjoin to the next room to form a 2 bedroom suite. It was fine until the next room occupants came home and then we could hear everything including them using the restroom. At 9pm we asked if we could have another room. They gave us another room but our new room had a broken air conditioner (hot!) and the shower kept going from cold to hot. I ordered a small salad snack from room service. It took over 45 mins to get my salad delivered to my room (a salad!!??). The next morning when we went to make reservations at the Hau Tree Lani (great restaurant by the way) they told us they couldn’t fit us in for 2 hours but they ‘squeezed’ us in. Then when we went to the restaurant, they weren’t busy at all. Weird!In summary, the customer service was good (they did give us another room) but the rooms were crap and outdated. The room service was slow and I don’t even know what to think about the restaurant reservation issue. We won’t stay there again (we’ll spend the extra $30 and stay at the Lotus hotel next door)

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: What we liked : - the hotel was clean, the furniture was modern- the place was very calm, wich is very nice after spending an afternoon in Waikiki- the beach was uncrowded- the Hau Tree Lanai, were breakfast are taken, is really great- the service was nice and the cocktails were great- the view from our bed (palmtrees and the mountains)- the walk to Waikiki, through parks, is very niceWhat we didn't like : - the view from our lanai (rooftops and the parking lot)- the bedroom could use a refreshment (wallpaper, bathroom)- the AC : quite noisy- no bottle of water in the room- the price ;)It was exactly what we were looking for to visit Honolulu. And the Hau Tree Lanai is an incredible place to have breakfast !

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: I was very hesitant on writing a review, as I like to keep these gems to myself to avoid overcrowdedness. But if it wasn't for someone else writing a review, I would never have stayed there.  I could not ask for a better location. More quiet beach yet still walkable to waiki if need be. The breakfasts are fantastic - it kept us full untill dinner time. The staff all around were great, the room was clean and the view spectacular! It was probably the first time me and my spouse have ever had consitent nights of good, deep sleep. A combination of the matress, pillow, ocean sounds and the animal sounds from the zoo! We long to go back!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Wir wollten eigentlich weiter ausserhalb von Honululu uebernachten, da es aber auf Oahu ausserhalb Honolulu/Waikiki schwierig ist mit Hotels/Unterkuenften, mussten wir zurueck nach Waikiki und fanden dieses Hotel. Das Personal ist nicht ueberragend freundlich, aber ok. Unser Zimmer war im neunten Stock des Haupthauses mit Diamondhead Blick und (sehr windigem) Balkon. Da wir erst bei Dunkelheit ankamen, haben wir von der Umgebung nicht viel gesehen. Schoen war der Ausblick auf die Lichter auf den Bergen bei Honolulu. Shampoo, Bodylotion, etc ist von L'Occitane. Zimmer war sauber. Die Lueftung ist etwas laut, aber ok. Wifi ist gratis. Waikiki ist in Gehweite, aber weit. Parken kostet 18 Dollar pro Tag (gegenueber kann man gratis Parken von 6pm bis 10 am).Gutes Hotel, das wir auch bei Tag einmal anschauen wuerden.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Let me be clear, If you are one of those folks who is just looking for a great deal because you plan to be out of the hotel for hours on end and you are just going to crash there then my review may not be all that helpful. Most of the reviews praise the location as being on the "quiet side" of the beach, that is technically true you are basically in a residential area which is about a 15 - 20 minute walk to the outer portion of the action in Waikiki, basically as far as I am concerned Waikiki starts at LuLu's. If you are content with the round trip then by all means, however midday in the hot sun about halfway there I often wished I had opted to stay a little bit closer. The Hotel itself is directly on the beach which is a rarity for its pricepoint, however I wasn't terribly impressed by the beach, you are basically right next to a public park and there are any number of unpowered watercraft in the water in front of the hotel which makes swimming out too deep a bit a pain, the beach I found to be rather crowded even though I was of the impression it was for hotel guests however there is no mechanism for stopping anyone from walking on, so it may very well just be an extension of the public beach. The rooms were dated, and I am not talking 1990's more like the 1970's which I would have no issue with except I found the bed to be rather uncomfortable and the rooms to be very small. I understand for the price you get what you pay for, but the room is basically a bed with a TV across from it and a very small bathroom,I am not one to complain about smaller rooms as long as they are small and comfortable, this one was simply small and smelt very musty and I just couldn't get comfortable, that coupled with the very thin walls which resulted in me hearing my neighbor discussing their plans for the next day with perfect clarity did not help matters. You are paying for the fact that its on the beach, and if that is what you want then by all means, but I would seriously consider spending the same money and opting to walk across the street in a more active area of Waikiki.

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: Smaller hotel, slightly past its prime, but the location on the beach, across from Kapiolani Park and close to Diamond Head and a real neighborhood is wonderful! Waikiki is too crazy and busy for me, but I loved this quiet little hotel and it's a short walk to the busy part of Waikiki! Smaller room, but comfortable beds, fridge, free WiFi and hi-def flat screen TV. I had the mesmerizing "Scenic Hawaii 1000" TV channel with spectacular helicopter-shot footage of all the islands and relaxing music" on in the background whenever I was in the room. Nice quiet crowd in this hotel. I ran the scenic road around Diamond Head in the mornings. I'd definitely stay here again!

hotel_name: The New Otani Kaimana Beach Hotel
review_body: We stayed in room 812 for eight nights, on September 2nd through the 9th. It was an ocean-view deluxe room.First the negative:Renovations: The hotel and staff bills itself as newly renovated. Well, the carpet is new, and the bedding was fresh and comfortable, but that's about it with new renovations. The bathroom has peachish/pinkish colored tile with pink grout. The bathroom's wallpaper is pink and green, and the sink has a formica-like countertop over a painted plyboard cabinet. The bathroom's renovation hasn't happened since the 1980's. I feel a little duped by the hotel's website that states, "newly renovated", and shows picture of granite counters, etc... I wish they would be upfront and honest in their ads, and state not all rooms have the complete renovations pictured....when I called to confirm my reservations, the receptionist even stated specifically that all rooms have been newly renovated. A more honest statement would be all rooms have been at least "partially" renovated. The common areas of the hotel, atrium, etc... also do not appear to be newly renovated. The atrium has painted cinder block, the lobby has plain furniture that is outdated and worn. This hotel needs an infusion from an investor of 50 million or so, and it could be a premiere hotel. The potential is there...but, the investment just hasn't been made.Coffeemaker: There is not a coffeemaker in the room. Called the front desk, and one was brought up quickly. However, on the third day, the hotel did not leave any coffee for the coffeemaker. And, when we called the front desk again, we were told we had to request coffee on a daily basis? Really? What good is a coffeemaker without coffee? However, each of the remaining days, we were provided coffee, without having to further request it.Staff: The maid service was exceptional, and they were all very friendly and personable. But, all other staff at the hotel, front desk, travel, etc... were very lackadaisical. Most of the staff are Asian, and many of the clientelle are also asian, so maybe this is a cultural difference. But, from the pricepoint of this hotel, I expected a few more smiles and pleasantries. No one was rude. But, no one went out of their way to be friendly or helpful.Location: To get between the Waikiki strip and the hotel, you have to walk on the sidewalk near the street to get around the park, or the sidewalk near the ocean to get around the park. No biggie, except there are MANY homeless people camping out in Kapiloani Park, and this is a bit disconcerting at night. There are many signs in the park that says no overnight camping, tents, etc... but, obviously those laws are not enforced as there are tents, umbrellas and sleeping bags there at all hours of the night with people in them. I will say, I was never accosted, no one ever begged for money...and, I never felt specifically threatened. There was also always quite a few tourists out and about, so maybe there is safety in numbers. But, I am a guy, and am in shape, etc... I would be concerned for women and older folks walking through.Natatorium: Our room looked out at the ocean, park, Waikiki and the Natatorium. The Natatorium was once a grand WWI monument but now it is in a bad state of disrepair. From our room we could specifically see the holes in the concrete deck, the wooden plyboard partially covering the holes and the warning signs to keep out, etc... I hope the city renovates this historical place but, at the present it is an eyesore. Add, the eyesore to the homeless camped out and it is not an inviting picture.Restaurants: I ate breakfast and dinner at the Hau Tree. It was not necessarily to my liking. Amazing view. The service was o.k. Dinner cost 150.00 for two with drinks. Breakfast 50.00 for two. At this price, I expected a lot better food and service. I also ate dinner at the Myoku Restaurant. It was again about 150.00 for two with drinks. However, it was very good and the waitresses were dressed in Kimonos, which was a nice authentic touch. The view is amazing. But, the restaurant looked like some cheap Chinese restaurant off of the interestate. Again, it was probably last decorated in the 1980's. Atmosphere was disappointing. Obviously, the pictures for the internet were tweeked again to make it look a little more up to date than actual. And, for $150.00 I expect a nicer place.Internet: After spending several thousand dollars at this hotel, restaurant, parking and room, you would think they would print your airline boarding pass for you...but, nope...had to pay $5.00 at their money taking computer. Come on guys...this seems a little petty. Really you couldn't have spared a piece of paper?Late check out: Our red-eye flight was delayed to an 8 p.m. departure. I requested a late check-out of 4:30 p.m. , which the hotel accomodated. Eventhough there was no one booked for my room for that evening, they still charged $150.00! Again, really? I spent several thousand dollars with you, and you are still charging that much to stay a few hours later?
